author: CHARLIE SAVAGE and CATIE EDMONDSON
content: [ Read more about the documents, here. ] Sparks fly over “committee confidential” documents Even as The Times were publishing secret emails involving Judge Kavanaugh, the Judiciary Committee chairman, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, was trying to address Democra… [+3974 chars]
description: Protesters shout inside of Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Charles E. Grassley’s office before Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearing on Thursday.
title: Kavanugh Hearings Live Updates: Abortion Documents Take Center Stage
text:
Advertisement By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, CHARLIE SAVAGE and ADAM LIPTAKSEPT. 6, 2018
 Senators on the Judiciary Committee pressed Judge Brett Kavanaugh about the constitutional right to abortion and his views on the special counsel. â¢ The third day of confirmation hearings for the Supreme Court nominee Brett M. Kavanaugh, and the second day of senatorsâ questioning, began at 9:30 a.m. and stretched late into the night. â¢ The release of documents once marked âcommittee confidentialâ fortified Democratic questions on abortion, affirmative action and whether Judge Kavanaugh knew of Republican aidesâ theft of Democratic computer files. â¢ Many of those confidential documents spilled out in an anonymous release to The New York Times. Judge Kavanaughâs abortion views created a stir outside the hearing room. Adding to the concerns of abortion rights advocates was a Kavanaugh reference to contraceptives as âabortion-inducing drugs.â He was answering a question from Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, about his dissent in a case involving Priests for Life, a religious organization that objected to a regulation under the Affordable Care Act requiring many employers to provide free insurance coverage for contraception to their female workers. Advertisement The group had objected to an accommodation offered by the Obama administration that allowed it to obtain a waiver by completing a form. Advertisement âThey said filling out the form would make them complicit in the provision of the abortion inducing drugs that they were as a religious matter objecting to,â Judge Kavanaugh testified. Some religious organizations regard any form of birth control as an abortifacient. But Judge Kavanaughâs use of the term âabortion-inducing drugsâ set off alarm bells among abortion rights advocates and spawned a hashtag, #abortioninducingdrugs, on Twitter. Erica Sackin, director of political communications for Planned Parenthood of America, commented on Twitter: 
            BIG FLAG: #Kavanaugh just called birth control "abortion-inducing drugs"         Judge Kavanaugh would not say whether he thought the Supreme Courtâs 2015 decision establishing a constitutional right to same-sex marriage had been correctly decided. But he tried to convey sympathy for gay rights by quoting from a Supreme Court decision in June that sided with a Colorado baker who refused to create a wedding cake for a same-sex couple. The ruling did not address the central dispute in the case and turned instead on apparent hostility against religion in a state civil rights commission. Judge Kavanaugh focused on one statement in the majority opinion, written by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, the member of the court he hopes to replace. âOur society has come to the recognition that gay persons and gay couples cannot be treated as social outcasts or as inferior in dignity and worth,â Justice Kennedy wrote. Judge Kavanaugh noted that Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justices Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Neil M. Gorsuch, all members of the courtâs conservative wing, had joined the opinion. And he suggested that he agreed with the sentiment, too. Amid the arcane discussions of Supreme Court precedent and judicial philosophy, the Kavanaugh hearings did have some lighter moments. Advertisement Senator John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana, had some probing questions about Judge Kavanaughâs past: âDid you ever get in trouble? Were you more of a John Boy Walton type or a Ferris Bueller type?â The judge didnât bite. Mr. Cruz asked Judge Kavanaugh if he intends to play basketball at the court inside the Supreme Court building. No sitting justice has played there, Mr. Cruz said, since Justice Clarence Thomas, âmany years ago, when he was a much younger justice.â Judge Kavanaugh said that if confirmed, he does indeed intend to play, on what is known as âthe highest court in the land.â And speaking of basketball, Judge Kavanaugh is exceedingly proud of the girlsâ basketball teams he has coached through the Catholic Youth Organization at his home parish, Blessed Sacrament in Chevy Chase, Md. About a dozen current and former players â in blue sweaters, ponytails and plaid skirts â showed up to watch. They sat in the front rows, right behind their coach. Judge Kavanaugh introduced each of them, rattling off their names and, in a remarkable display of memory not devoted to legal precedent, their grades. âLetâs see,â he said. âWeâve got Liza going into fifth grade. Keeganâs in fifth. Annaâs in seventh. Shawnee is in seventh. Quinn is in sixth. Sophie is in seventh. So I think I got it all right.â The room broke out into applause. In documents obtained by The New York Times that date back to Judge Kavanaughâs time in the George W. Bush administration, Mr. Kavanaugh, then a White House aide, seemed to raise doubts about whether Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court ruling that found a constitutional right to an abortion, was âsettled law.â He was considering a draft opinion piece to be run under the names of anti-abortion women that stated, âit is widely accepted by legal scholars across the board that Roe v. Wade and its progeny are the settled law of the land.â Responding to the email, the future Supreme Court nominee wrote, âI am not sure that all legal scholars refer to Roe as the settled law of the land at the Supreme Court level since Court can always overrule its precedent, and three current Justices on the Court would do so.â Advertisement The documents do not indicate how Judge Kavanaugh would rule, but they are fodder for Democratic questioning. Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the ranking Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, asked Mr. Kavanaugh about the document, noting it had been made public. Mr. Kavanaugh defended the statement he made in the email, and said âthe broader point was simply that it was overstating something about legal scholars.â âIâm always concerned about accuracy, and I thought it was not an accurate description of all legal scholars,â he said, adding later that Roe v. Wade is âan important precedent. It has been reaffirmed many times.â He declined to comment directly on Ms. Feinsteinâs questions as to whether it is âcorrect law.â NARAL Pro-Choice America, the abortion rights lobby, jumped on the release immediately: âBrett Kavanaughâs emails are rock solid evidence that he has been hiding his true beliefs and if he is given a lifetime seat on the Supreme Court, he will gut Roe v. Wade, criminalize abortion, and punish women. Everything he said yesterday in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee about âsettled lawâ was nothing but a show to mislead the Senate.â [Read more about the documents, here.] A tantalizing moment on Wednesday came when Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, asked Judge Kavanaugh whether he had meetings with Manuel Miranda, a former Senate Republican aide who was caught stealing files from the computers of Senate Judiciary Committee Democrats, including Mr. Leahy. Judge Kavanaugh denied ever knowingly receiving stolen material when he was a White House aide tasked with getting President George W. Bushâs judicial nominees confirmed. On Thursday, questioning Judge Kavanaugh a second time, Mr. Leahy described and put up on posters several emails about his interactions with Mr. Miranda, indicating that he had received permission from the committee chairman around 3 a.m. to disclose them. They included a March 2003 email from Mr. Miranda to Judge Kavanaugh that included several pages of Democratic talking points, marked ânot for distribution,â and another to Judge Kavanaugh from a Republican Senate staff member whose subject line âspyingâ and which referred to âa mole for us on the left.â 
            Subject: spying pic.twitter.com/GuIGHCjwiE  Judge Kavanaugh reiterated that he had no knowledge that Mr. Miranda had infiltrated Democratic files, saying he likely assumed that the Republican staff was getting information from friends who were Democratic staff members and nothing had raised red flags at the time. Advertisement âI was born at night but not last night,â Mr. Leahy said. âIf I had something that somebody said, we have stolen this or donât tell anybody we have this, I think it would raise some red flags.â Mr. Leahy also pressed him about more than 100,000 documents from his period as a Bush White House lawyer that the Senate has not been permitted to see, even on a confidential basis, because a lawyer for President Bush has said they are subject to executive privilege. Mr. Leahy asked whether Judge Kavanaugh could confirm that none of those contain more such emails from Mr. Miranda.  Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. âSenator, I am not involved in the documents process,â Judge Kavanaugh. âI donât know whatâs in them.â Replied Mr. Leahy: âThat is convenient.â Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, pressed Mr. Kavanaugh on comments he made in support of Justice Antonin Scaliaâs dissent in a case that upheld the constitutionality of an independent counsel. âGiven your views on Morrison v. Olson, we are obviously worried you will feel bound by this dissent by Scalia if President Trump decides to attempt to fire the special counsel Bob Mueller,â Mr. Durbin said. Mr. Kavanaugh began by pushing back on the framing of Mr. Durbinâs question, noting that case involved the creation of an independent counsel, not a special counsel. But ultimately, he assured the senator, âIâve made clear in my writing that when a court order requires a president to do something or prohibits a president from doing something under the constitution or laws of the United States, that is the final word.â When it comes to the scope of executive power, he said, âI am one not afraid at all in my record of twelve years to invalidate executive power when it violates the law.â Later, under questioning from Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, Judge Kavanaugh pushed back against what he called a misinterpretation of a comment he made at a 1999 round table, when he said, âMaybe Nixon was wrongly decided â heresy though it is to say so.â He was referring to the 1974 case of United States v. Nixon, where the Supreme Courtâs ruled unanimously that a sitting president, Richard M. Nixon, could be subpoenaed for documents and records like the Watergate tape recordings. Judge Kavanaugh said he was being wry, and critiquing the strategy of lawyers for President Bill Clinton during the investigation of that president. âThe tone of voice there has made the printed word look much different than how it was intended,â he said, adding that he believes the case was correctly decided, and is âone of the four greatest decisionsâ in Supreme Court history. (He did not say what the other three are.) Advertisement Much of the morning was given to what appeared to be real drama, the move by Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, to release âcommittee confidentialâ documents without Republican permission â and Republican threats to exact consequences. After all, such a release could result in Mr. Bookerâs expulsion from Senate. âBring it,â the senator said. Senators Booker and Mazie K. Hirono, Democrat of Hawaii, went ahead and released the documents. âThis is about the closest Iâll ever come in my life to an âI am Spartacusâ moment,â Mr. Booker declared. But after the drama subsided, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said all of those documents were cleared for release overnight. William A. Burck, the former Bush White House lawyer tasked with reviewing the Kavanaugh documents, said in a statement, âWe cleared the documents last night shortly after Senator Bookerâs staff asked us to. We were surprised to learn about Senator Bookerâs histrionics this morning because we had already told him he could use the documents publicly. In fact, we have said yes to every request made by the Senate Democrats to make documents public.â The question remains, so why were Republicans handing Mr. Booker his moment, not saying, hey, whatâs the big deal? As for Mr. Booker, his spokeswoman gave him credit for forcing the documentsâ release â and said this would not be the last of the document kerfuffles. âCory and Senate Democrats were able to shame the committee into agreeing to make last nightâs documents publicly available, and Cory publicly released those documents as well as other committee confidential documents today,â the spokeswoman, Kristin Lynch, said in a statement. âAnd heâll keep releasing them because Republicans are hiding Brett Kavanaughâs record from the American people.â Advertisement Late in Wednesdayâs proceedings, the questioning finally reached Senator Kamala Harris, Democrat of California, and she launched into tense questioning that centered around whether Judge Kavanaugh had ever discussed the Russia investigation by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, with a lawyer or lawyers from the law firm of President Trumpâs longtime personal lawyer, Marc Kasowitz. 
            Has Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh had a conversation about Robert Mueller or his investigation with anyone at Trump's personal attorney's law firm?We donât know. He refused to answer my question. pic.twitter.com/PAKxDGvEtZ  Judge Kavanaugh appeared somewhat baffled, but he would not offer a blanket ânoâ because he said he didnât know the names of every lawyer who worked for the firm, and he had discussed the Mueller investigation with lawyers and judges. âI think youâre thinking of someone, and you donât want to tell us,â Ms. Harris said without elaboration. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, gave Judge Kavanaugh an opportunity on Thursday to revisit Ms. Harrisâs line of questioning. Mr. Kavanaugh responded by acknowledging he doesnât know everyone who works at the firm, but said, âI donât recall any conversations of that kind.â âI havenât had any inappropriate conversations about that investigation with anyone,â Judge Kavanaugh said. âIâve never given anyone any winks, hints, forecasts, previews, nothing, about my view as a judge, or how I would rule as a judge on that or anything related to that.â A spokesman for Kasowitz Benson Torres said in a statement Thursday that âthere have been no discussions regarding Robert Muellerâs investigation between Judge Kavanaugh and anyone at our firm.â In a letter last June to Mr. Mueller, Mr. Kasowitz cited a majority opinion by Judge Kavanaugh, without naming him, saying, âThe President may decline to prosecute certain violators of federal law just as the President may pardon certain violators of federal law. The President may decline to prosecute or may pardon because of the Presidentâs own constitutional concerns about a law or because of policy objections to the law, among other reasons.â The question is, can and will the senator tell the public what she knows? Most Supreme Court nominees express enthusiasm for cameras in the court at their confirmation hearings, only to change their minds after they join the court. Judge Kavanaugh took a different approach, saying only that âI will have an open mind on it.â Advertisement He said his current court, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, has recently allowed live audio coverage of its arguments. That development, he said, was a positive one. But he offered only vague comments on electronic coverage of the Supreme Court. The court generally releases audio recording of arguments at the end of the week and does not allow camera coverage. Judge Kavanaugh made one novel suggestion, offering that the court should consider camera coverage of the sessions in which the justices summarize their opinions from the bench. The court, which currently releases audio of those sessions months later, is unlikely to adopt the idea. The justices may be wary of suggesting to the public that their informal oral summaries, rather than their written opinions, precisely set out the details of decisions. See More » Go to Home Page »

content: 10. Finally, after 13 years, Dorothy’s ruby slippers have been found. One of the famous pairs Judy Garland wore in “The Wizard of Oz” was stolen from a museum in Grand Rapids, Minn. Without fingerprints or surveillance video, the authorities were stumped. At … [+631 chars]
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
title: Brett Kavanaugh, Colin Kaepernick, Amazon: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: Advertisement Supported by By Joumana Khatib, Stephen Reiss and Sandra Stevenson (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) Good evening. Hereâs the latest. 1. It was the first day of confirmation hearings for Judge Brett Kavanaughâs appointment to the Supreme Court, and it started with a bang. Senate Democrats moved angrily to adjourn to consider tens of thousands of pages of documents released the night before the hearing. They were joined by crowds of protesters, who cried out their support. President Trumpâs potential legal troubles were a recurring theme, but Republicans praised Judge Kavanaugh and expressed confidence he will be confirmed. The hearings continue through the week. _____ 2. Voters in Massachusetts went to the polls today and elected Ayanna Pressley, 44, above, over 10-term Representative Michael Capuano in a Democratic primary that few said she could win. She is now poised to become the first African-American in the state to be elected to the House of Representatives. Separately, the White House and President Trump are rattled by a forthcoming book that portrays the administration as an out-of-control operation: âcrazytown,â in the reported words of the chief of staff, John Kelly. According to the book, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said âthe president acted like â and had the understanding of â a âfifth or sixth grader.ââ Thatâs among the most explosive claims in âFear,â by Bob Woodward, due out next week. The Times obtained a copy. _____ 3. Even after news that Colin Kaepernick had signed a multimillion-dollar deal with Nike and become a face of its âJust Do Itâ campaign, his silence is deafening. The former quarterback started kneeling in protest during the national anthem before N.F.L. games in 2016, and other players soon joined him. Their protest caused a huge outcry, dividing fans and the league owners, captivating celebrities and athletes and motivating President Trump to persistently tweet his anger over it. But Mr. Kaepernick is letting his social media savvy â and a total rejection of interviews â spin the message. _____ 4. $1,000,000,000,000. Amazon became the second American company to reach a market value of $1 trillion. Apple hit that milestone last month, but with Amazon, our reporter writes, the path has been much more complicated. Amazon has revolutionized how people shop â and taught retailers some hard lessons along the way. But thereâs also been a rise in its brick-and-mortar operations. _____ 5. Other tech giants are under scrutiny over the coming midterm elections. Executives from Facebook, Twitter and Google will testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Wednesday about their preparations to thwart foreign influence campaigns and disinformation. Sheryl Sandberg, Facebookâs C.O.O., above. The power their platforms wield over public discourse is enormous. Temporarily barring Alex Jones of Infowars â who regularly spreads lies, conspiracy theories and inflammatory attacks against political enemies â drastically reduced his reach. Over the summer, Facebook announced the discovery of hundreds of fake pages and user accounts on its site. Can you tell the difference between a genuine Facebook post and one that was part of an influence campaign? Try your hand with our quiz. _____ 6. Another worry for Facebook: In Libya, it has become a platform for âkeyboard warriorsâ who stoke violence. In the capital, where violence has broken out between rival militias in recent days, some combatants picked up rocket launchers. Others headed online. âKeyboard warriors,â as Facebook partisans are known in Libya, issued boasts, taunts and chilling threats online as their counterparts attacked from the ground. Some Facebook users even provided direct coordinates for targeted attacks. Facebook insists it is policing its Libyan platform, but illegal activity is rife. _____ 7. A replacement for John McCain: John Kyl, a former Arizona senator, will fill the seat, though he has committed to serving only until the start of the next Congress, in January. Mr. Kyl has been helping Judge Brett Kavanaugh through the confirmation process. In tapping him to fill it, Gov. Doug Ducey has effectively put the stature of Mr. McCainâs seat ahead of the political imperative of keeping it in Republican hands, our reporter writes. And in Chicago, Mayor Rahm Emanuel, above, announced he would not seek re-election. âThis has been the job of a lifetime, but it is not a job for a lifetime,â he said. _____ 8. Tropical Storm Gordon is heading for the Gulf Coast and is poised to become the first hurricane to strike the continental United States this year. Itâs expected to intensify into a Category 1 hurricane before it makes landfall along the Gulf Coast late Tuesday or early Wednesday. Forecasters donât anticipate the kind of damage that Hurricane Harvey caused a year ago, but the governors of Alabama, Louisiana and Mississippi have all declared states of emergency. Weâll have live updates about the storm. _____ 9. News from the U.S. Open: Sloane Stephens, the defending champion, lost in the U.S. Open quarterfinals to Anastasija Sevastova, above, on Tuesday. Karolina Pliskova will take on Serena Williams this evening. Check back for live updates and results. And in case you missed it, Roger Federer lost last night to John Millman. He blamed the heat. (Yes, itâs still hot.) _____ 10. Finally, after 13 years, Dorothyâs ruby slippers have been found. One of the famous pairs Judy Garland wore in âThe Wizard of Ozâ was stolen from a museum in Grand Rapids, Minn. Without fingerprints or surveillance video, the authorities were stumped. At one point a private donor even offered a $1 million reward. The F.B.I. announced Tuesday that the stolen slippers had been found, but did not reveal any suspects in a case that captivated fans. As one put it: âThere isnât anything else that does more to evoke the power of belief.â Have a great night. _____ Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern. And donât miss Your Morning Briefing. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. Want to catch up on past briefings? You can browse them here. What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com. Advertisement

content: Mr. Kavanaugh listed ten possible questions based on Ms. Lewinsky’s testimony, saying that he would “leave the best phrasing to others.” Among them were these: “If Monica Lewinsky says that you had phone sex with her on approximately 15 occasions, would she b… [+1023 chars]
description: A newly released memo shows that Brett M. Kavanaugh took a relentlessly tough stance as a young lawyer investigating President Clinton’s affair with an intern.
title: Brett Kavanaugh Urged Graphic Questions in Clinton Probe
text: Advertisement Supported by By Adam Liptak WASHINGTON â Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trumpâs Supreme Court nominee, urged prosecutors investigating President Bill Clinton to question him in graphic detail about his sexual relationship with Monica Lewinsky, a White House intern, according to a memorandum released on Monday by the National Archives. Mr. Kavanaugh spent more than three years working for Ken Starr, the independent counsel who investigated a series of scandals during Mr. Clintonâs presidency, and he worked on the report that led the House of Representatives to impeach Mr. Clinton. Mr. Kavanaugh drew up the memo as other members of Mr. Starrâs team were preparing to question Mr. Clinton. The memo, dated Aug. 15, 1998, was shot through with disgust for Mr. Clintonâs behavior and seemed animated by the deep animosity that had developed between the White House and Mr. Starrâs team. The document betrayed deep hostility to Mr. Clinton, and it included 10 proposed questions about matters like oral sex and masturbation. Former members of Mr. Starrâs team have said that Mr. Kavanaugh, who is now a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, immediately regretted its tone. [Read the memo here.] But in the memo, he was unrelenting. âThe president has disgraced his office, the legal system and the American people by having sex with a 22-year-old intern and turning her life into a shambles â callous and disgusting behavior that has somehow gotten lost in the shuffle,â Mr. Kavanaugh wrote. âHe has committed perjury (at least) in the Jones case,â Mr. Kavanaugh wrote, referring to the sexual harassment case brought by Paula Jones, an Arkansas state worker who said Mr. Clinton had made lewd advances toward her in a hotel room when he was governor. âHe has lied to his aides,â Mr. Kavanaugh wrote. âHe has lied to the American people. He has tried to disgrace youâ â meaning Mr. Starr â âand this office with a sustained propaganda campaign that would make Nixon blush.â âIt may not be our job to impose sanctions on him, but it is our job to make his pattern of revolting behavior clear â piece by painful piece,â Mr. Kavanaugh wrote. âArenât we failing to fulfill our duty to the American people if we willingly âconspireâ with the president in an effort to conceal the true nature of his acts?â To that end, Mr. Kavanaugh wrote, Mr. Clinton should be asked extremely detailed questions unless he first either resigned or admitted to perjury and publicly apologized to Mr. Starr. Mr. Kavanaugh listed 10 possible questions based on Ms. Lewinskyâs testimony, saying that he would âleave the best phrasing to others.â Among them were these: âIf Monica Lewinsky says that you had phone sex with her on approximately 15 occasions, would she be lying?â âIf Monica Lewinsky says that you ejaculated into her mouth on two occasions in the Oval Office area, would she be lying?â âIf Monica Lewinsky says that you masturbated into a trash can in your secretaryâs office, would she be lying?â The substance of the memo has long been available, notably in a 2010 book, âThe Death of American Virtue: Clinton vs. Starr,â by Ken Gormley. But the full memo had not been made public until Monday, and it provided striking details about the hard line Mr. Kavanaugh urged his colleagues to take. In an interview this month, Robert J. Bittman, the deputy counsel who led the Lewinsky prosecution for Mr. Starr, said Mr. Kavanaugh had recognized that the memo was a misstep. âBrett immediately regretted the tone of that memo,â Mr. Bittman said. âMy memory is that he was sleep deprived and then quickly realized in retrospect that it was over the top.â Mr. Kavanaugh took a different approach when Mr. Starr was about to provide Congress with a report laying out possible grounds for impeachment, urging his colleagues to use discretion in describing Mr. Clintonâs interactions with Ms. Lewinsky. He lost that fight. The final report included all of the sexual details, and it was quickly made available on the internet. In the memo, Mr. Kavanaugh said he was âmindful of the need to respect the office of the president.â âBut in my view,â he continued, âgiven what we know, the interests of the office of the president would best be served by gathering the full facts regarding the actions of this president so that the Congress can decide whether the interests of the presidency would best be served by having a new president.â The memo was released as tensions between Mr. Trump and Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating links between Mr. Trump and Russia, seem to be rising with each passing day. Judge Kavanaugh seems certain to be questioned about the memo and what it suggests about the Mueller investigation at his confirmation hearings next month. Judge Kavanaugh is likely to say that his views on the wisdom of criminal investigations of sitting presidents have evolved considerably in the two decades since he wrote the memo. âI believe that the president should be excused from some of the burdens of ordinary citizenship while serving in office,â he wrote in 2009 in the Minnesota Law Review, after an extended stint in the George W. Bush White House and after he became a judge. Among those burdens, Judge Kavanaugh wrote, were responding to civil lawsuits and criminal charges. He said Congress should consider imposing limits on such proceedings. âEven the lesser burdens of a criminal investigation â including preparing for questioning by criminal investigators â are time-consuming and distracting,â Judge Kavanaugh wrote. âLike civil suits, criminal investigations take the presidentâs focus away from his or her responsibilities to the people. And a president who is concerned about an ongoing criminal investigation is almost inevitably going to do a worse job as president.â Judge Kavanaugh said that the proceedings could resume after a president left office and that impeachment remained an option before then. His years of service as staff secretary to Mr. Bush had altered his understanding of the all-consuming nature of the presidency, he wrote in 2009, at the start of the Obama administration. The investigation of Mr. Clinton, he wrote, had been misguided. âLike many Americans at that time, I believed that the president should be required to shoulder the same obligations that we all carry,â he wrote. âBut in retrospect, that seems a mistake. âLooking back to the late 1990s, for example,â Judge Kavanaugh wrote, âthe nation certainly would have been better off if President Clinton could have focused on Osama bin Laden without being distracted by the Paula Jones sexual harassment case and its criminal investigation offshoots.â At the time, though, Mr. Kavanaugh took a hard line, aghast that Mr. Clinton had lied and tarnished the presidency â âall to cover up his oral sex from an intern.â Michael D. Shear contributed reporting. Follow Adam Liptak on Twitter: @adamliptak.  Advertisement
