description: Senators on the Judiciary Committee pressed Judge Brett Kavanaugh on Thursday about the constitutional right to abortion and his views on the special counsel.
title: Brett Kavanaugh, Burt Reynolds, North Korea: Your Friday Briefing
text: Advertisement Supported by By Daniel Victor  (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) Good morning. Hereâs what you need to know: â¢ The leak of previously secret documents on Thursday injected fresh intrigue into the confirmation hearings of President Trumpâs Supreme Court nominee, as Democrats pressed the judge to explain his comments on abortion rights and affirmative action. In one email from 2003, he appeared to challenge whether Roe v. Wade was the âsettled law of the land.â On Thursday, Judge Kavanaugh said that the comment reflected âan accurate description of all legal scholars.â Republicans, who continue to support his appointment to the Supreme Court, discarded the revelations as insignificant. Hereâs an overview of Judge Kavanaughâs record on civil rights, and a recap of what happened on Thursday. Our politics team will have coverage when the hearings resume at 9:30 a.m. Eastern. â¢ The confirmation process has been like a campaign audition for Democrats eyeing a 2020 presidential run. â¢ One by one, top officials lined up on Thursday to say they had nothing to do with the unsigned essay in The Times that was sharply critical of President Trump. The White House started a furious mole hunt. The public played an obsessive guessing game. Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, directed her Twitter followers to call the main switchboard of The Times to ask who wrote the piece. (Weâre always happy to hear from readers, but our operators donât know the authorâs identity, nor was it shared with news reporters covering the White House.) Hereâs how writers from the left and the right have reacted to the Op-Ed. And we explain the 25th Amendment, a mechanism to declare a president unfit for office that the essay said had been considered. â¢ Mr. Trump sought to regain control of the political conversation at a rally Thursday night in Montana, where he looked at home in front of a jubilant audience. â¢ With Roman Catholics clamoring for more transparency, attorneys general are aggressively investigating possible sexual abuse by clergy members. On Thursday alone, all eight Catholic dioceses in New York were issued subpoenas, and the New Jersey attorney general announced an inquiry. âI was deeply troubled to read the allegations contained in last monthâs Pennsylvania grand jury report,â the attorney general said in a statement. âWe owe it to the people of New Jersey to find out whether the same thing happened here.â â¢ Attorneys general in Illinois, Missouri, Nebraska and New Mexico have also said they will look into their local institutions. â¢ With one hairy-chested centerfold for Cosmopolitan in 1972, the heartthrob actor broke taboos and changed cultural understandings of the female gaze. Mr. Reynolds, who delighted audiences for four decades, died on Thursday at 82. To many in Hollywood, he was an enigma, both strong-willed and tormented by self-doubt. âI think Iâm the only movie star whoâs a movie star in spite of his pictures, not because of them; Iâve had some real turkeys,â he told The Times in 1978. â¢ That steamy centerfold? He came to regret it. âIt was really stupid. I donât know what I was thinking,â he said in 2016. â¢ The U.S. economy  gained 201,000 jobs in August, the Labor Department reported today. That was slightly more than analysts had expected. The unemployment rate remained at 3.9 percent. â¢ North Korean hackers caused hundreds of millions of dollars in damage to the global economy, the Justice Department said in a criminal complaint on Thursday. â¢ Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of CBS who has been accused of sexual harassment, is said to be negotiating his exit. â¢ President Trumpâs tweets have done little lasting harm to the businesses he attacks, as their stocks typically recover. â¢ U.S. stocks were mixed on Thursday. Hereâs a snapshot of global markets today. Tips for a more fulfilling life. â¢ Want a raise? Ask for one. â¢ Money isnât the easiest thing to handle. Get better at it. â¢ Recipe of the day: This buttery tart with a fruit filling is based on a gÃ¢teau Breton. â¢ The road to tragedy The Times reconstructed how a bridge collapsed in Genoa, Italy, in August, a disaster that killed 43 people. â¢ There wonât be a âPopularâ Oscar category after all The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences scrapped its unpopular plan to add the award. â¢ At the U.S. Open Naomi Osaka, the No. 20 seed from Japan, will play Serena Williams in the womenâs final on Saturday. Rafael Nadal faces Juan MartÃ­n del Potro in the semifinals today, and Novak Djokovic plays Kei Nishikori. Follow all of our tennis coverage here. â¢ The week in good news A tablet designed for visually impaired people could have an enormous impact. Itâs one of seven stories that inspired us. â¢ No news quiz this week It will return next Friday. â¢ Ready for the weekend At the movies, we recommend âFive Fingers for Marseilles,â a post-apartheid drama and western set in South Africa, and âBlaze,â a biopic of the country singer Blaze Foley, directed by Ethan Hawke. On TV, a charity telecast will bring actors and musicians together to raise money for cancer research, and we have some streaming recommendations. We suggest 11 new books, and, if youâre in New York City, a slate of cultural events. â¢ Best of late-night TV Seth Meyers poked fun at President Trumpâs response to the anonymous Op-Ed: âTrump tweeted, quote, âTREASON?â Even weirder, Mike Pence tweeted back, âSure! Letâs do it!â â â¢ Quotation of the day âIf you lose one stay, the whole thing comes down.â Andrew Herrmann, a former president of the American Society of Civil Engineers, describing risks in the design of the collapsed bridge in Genoa. â¢ The Times, in other words Hereâs an image of todayâs front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles. â¢ What weâre reading Michael Roston, a senior staff editor on the Science desk, recommends this podcast episode: âRose Evelethâs recounting of American researchers living on the ocean floor is fascinating. If thatâs not enough of an inducement to listen to her Flash Forward podcast, wait until you hear the recordings she surfaced of the âaquanauts,â breathing a mixture of helium and oxygen, trying to call President Lyndon B. Johnson.â [Editorâs note: We know thatâs listening, not reading. But weâre stuck trying to come up with a better label than âWhat Weâre Reading.â Got one? Let us know.] âGrandma Moses,â the acclaimed American painter who became a prototype for late bloomers, was born on this day in 1860. Anna Mary Robertson Moses, an upstate New York farm wife, began painting seriously in her 70s. She was discovered by a collector who saw her colorful, precise paintings of rural scenes in a drugstore window. After her first show, she was seized on by the press, who loved her countrified ways. An early reviewer nicknamed her âGrandma Moses.â The Times highlighted her folksiness when she visited Manhattan in 1940: âModest âGrandma Mosesâ declared, âIf they want to make a fuss over me, I guess I donât mind.ââ But Moses was no naÃ¯f. A believer in womenâs autonomy, she said in her autobiography: âAlways wanted to be independent. I couldnât bear the thought of sitting down and Thomas,â her husband, âhanding out the money.â And her âprimitiveâ painting style was carefully conceived: âI like to paint something that leads me on and on in to the unknown something that I want to see away on beyond,â she wrote. She died at 101, having created some 2,000 paintings and received two honorary doctorates. âAll Americans mourn her loss,â President John F. Kennedy said. Nancy Wartik wrote todayâs Back Story. _____ Your Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. To receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, sign up here. Check out our full range of free newsletters here. What would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com. Follow Daniel Victor on Twitter: @bydanielvictor. Advertisement

author: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
content: It did not take long — just 13 words — for Senator Kamala Harris to jump in. The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee had just gaveled the first day of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearings to order and was about to utter his 14th word when M… [+1073 chars]
description: From the moment Brett M. Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearings began, Senate Democrats eyeing a White House run in 2020 have used the live television event as a proving ground.
title: Democrats Grilling Kavanaugh Have Their Eyes on 2020
text: Advertisement Supported by By Sheryl Gay Stolberg WASHINGTON â The questioning of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh had not even begun Thursday morning when Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, threatened to release secret emails â even if it meant being expelled from the Senate. âThis is about the closest Iâll ever come in my life to an âI am Spartacusâ moment,â the senator declared with a flourish. It was a made-for-television moment â albeit later mocked by Republicans as grandstanding â and for Mr. Booker, it might come in handy. He is one of three Democrats on the Judiciary Committee â the others are Senators Kamala D. Harris of California and Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota â said to be contemplating presidential runs in 2020, and there is no time like a stately, nationally televised Supreme Court nomination hearing to grab the attention of the news media and amass valuable footage for future campaign commercials. Other 2020 hopefuls, notably Senators Kirsten Gillibrand of New York and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, have been making their own moves this week. Ms. Gillibrand, who has positioned herself as a leading advocate for womenâs rights, has been appearing with womenâs groups to protest the nomination, calling it âa clear threat to rights that women all across America hold dear.â And Ms. Warren, notoriously press shy in the corridors of the Capitol, told Politico on Wednesday that she intended to âopen upâ and start giving hallway interviews. But for Ms. Harris and Mr. Booker â and to a lesser extent, Ms. Klobuchar, who is less given to high drama â the hearings have been something like a campaign audition, not to mention the criticism that goes along with it. âRunning for president is no excuse for violating the rules of the Senate or of confidentiality of the documents that we are privy to,â Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, snapped after Mr. Booker made his threat about the emails. (It turned out that Mr. Booker had permission to make those messages public after all, prompting another Republican, Senator Thom Tillis of North Carolina, to quip, âYou didnât have to be Spartacus.â) It did not take long â just 13 words into the start of the first day of the hearings â for Ms. Harris to make her mark. The chairman of the Judiciary Committee had just gaveled hearings to order and was about to utter his 14th word when the California senator interrupted, demanding a delay to give the panel time to review a last-minute document dump. âWe cannot possibly move forward,â she protested, as the chairman, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, promptly ruled her out of order. Throughout the hearings, Ms. Harris, once the California attorney general, drew on her formidable skills as a former prosecutor to repeatedly skewer Judge Kavanaugh and back him into unpleasant corners. âCan you think of any laws that give the government the power to make decisions about the male body?â she asked at one point, in an exchange that picked up considerable traction on social media. The judge seemed flustered. âIâm not â Iâm not â thinking of any right now, senator,â he replied. Mr. Booker, for his part, proved his skills at oratory; on Wednesday night, he talked for 23 of the 30 minutes he was allotted to question Judge Kavanaugh, delivering a soaring lecture on racial inequality â even as he repeatedly cut off the nominee while grilling him about his views on affirmative action, racial profiling and voter identification laws. âIt seems that you are O.K. with using race to single out some Americans for extra security measures because they look different, but youâre not O.K. with using race to help promote diversity,â Mr. Booker said at one point, while disclosing that the committee had a confidential email titled âracial profilingâ relating to Judge Kavanaugh. For Mr. Booker and Ms. Harris, both darlings of the progressive movement, the hearings are also a chance to demonstrate fidelity to the left. Progressives have become increasingly frustrated with the way Senate Democrats are handling Judge Kavanaughâs nomination; on Wednesday, more than a dozen groups sent a scathing letter to Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, accusing him of allowing moderate Democrats to go their own way in considering whether to vote for confirmation. âAnything less than 49 Democratic votes against Kavanaugh would be a massive failure of your leadership,â read the letter, organized by Credo Action, which bills itself as a social-change network. Republicans, on the other hand, are accusing the Democrats of playing politics with one of the most sacred duties of the Senate: the responsibility to advise and consent on a Supreme Court nomination. Mr. Booker came under withering criticism on Wednesday when he sent a letter to supporters asking for signatures opposing Judge Kavanaugh. The letter, which circulated on Twitter, asked recipients to click through to a website that offered tickets to a coming New Jersey Democratic State Committee event. Then, on Thursday, Ms. Harris sent out her own fund-raising email, spotlighting her does-the-government-have-the-power-to-regulate-the-male-body exchange with Judge Kavanaugh. âI know youâre standing with me in this fight, and I appreciate everything youâve done so far,â the missive said, above a bright red link that declared, in all caps, Contribute. Republicans sneered. As Mr. Cornyn, the No. 2 Republican in the Senate, wrote on Twitter, âIt is all about the 2020 Democrat presidential primary.â   video Advertisement

author: EMILY COCHRANE
content: He will be introduced by Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio; Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state; and Lisa Blatt, a self-described “ liberal Democrat and a feminist ” lawyer who has advocated Judge Kavanaugh’s confirmation. In defense of pres… [+3501 chars]
description: Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh will appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday to present himself and answer questions from lawmakers. Here’s what to watch.
title: What to Watch: The First Day of Judge Kavanaugh’s Confirmation Hearings
text:
Advertisement By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, ADAM LIPTAK and CHARLIE SAVAGESEPT. 4, 2018
 The Latest: Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh has concluded his opening statement. The committee will resume his confirmation hearings at 9:30 a.m. Wednesday. Hereâs the latest. â¢ Democrats turned the opening into a brawl, but Republicans pushed through. Opening statements in the hearing were delayed by more than an hour as Democratic senators complained about the limits on their access to documents from Judge Kavanaughâs tenure in the Bush administration White House and pressed to adjourn. With protesters shouting and being removed from the room, Democrats sought a vote to postpone the hearing but were denied it. The frequent interruptions led one Republican, Senator John Cornyn of Texas, to call the opening of the hearing âmob rule.â But the committee chairman, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, refused to delay the hearingâs opening day and got through it by about 5 p.m. [Democrats sought to portray Judge Kavanaugh as a hopeless partisan.] â¢ Trumpâs potential legal troubles were a recurring theme. Many Democrats brought up statements by Judge Kavanaugh suggesting that he would be sympathetic to a sitting president who challenged a subpoena for testimony or an indictment. They suggested that President Trump may have picked him from the ranks of conservative jurists because he was hoping for an ally on the court, should Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating the Trump campaignâs ties to Russia, move against the president. Advertisement â¢ Republicans praised Kavanaugh and expressed confidence he will be confirmed. Republicans used their opening statements to praise Judge Kavanaugh as highly qualified and a good man. They accused Democrats of hypocrisy and argued that his 12 years of appeals court rulings, which are public, are the best way to evaluate what kind of Supreme Court justice he would be. And, secure in the knowledge that they control the Senate and can confirmed the judge with a simple majority vote, Republicans expressed confidence that however unruly things get, the Senate will ultimately approve his appointment. Advertisement â¢ The hearing foreshadowed likely Democratic frustration in coming days.  Democrats signaled in their opening statements that they intend to press Judge Kavanaugh to explain in detail what he thinks about contentious legal questions, especially whether the Roe v. Wade abortion rights decision was rightly decided â an issue that could illuminate whether he views it as settled precedent or vulnerable to overturning. But Republicans like Mr. Grassley said it would be inappropriate for him to indicate how he might rule on anything that might come before the court in the future. In his prepared opening statement, Judge Kavanaugh laid the groundwork for disclaiming that he will bring any ideological lens to interpreting ambiguous constitutional text, invoking the ideal of a judge as an âumpire â a neutral and impartial arbiter who favors no litigant or policy.â The hearing is scheduled to resume at 9:30 a.m. on Wednesday, starting with questioning by Mr. Grassley and by Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the ranking Democrat. Each senator on the committee will have 30 minutes in the first round of questioning and 20 in a second round, which is expected to wrap up on Thursday. Judge Kavanaugh would then be excused, and the senators will question a panel of legal experts who support and oppose his confirmation. Canât get enough? The rest of our dispatches from the day are below.  One of the biggest points of tension in the Kavanaugh confirmation hearings will be Judge Kavanaughâs response to Democratsâ questions about whether he believes certain cases â notably Roe v. Wade, the 1973 landmark decision establishing a constitutional right to abortion â have been correctly decided. In his opening statement, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the Judiciary Committee chairman, laid the groundwork for Judge Kavanaugh to refuse to answer, by invoking what has come to be known as the âGinsburg rule,â after Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who was appointed by a Democratic president, Bill Clinton. [Read Judge Kavanaughâs opening statement.] Declaring that it would be âunfair and unethicalâ for the judge to answer questions about specific cases, Mr. Grassley said: âItâs my advice to him to follow the example set by Judge Ginsburg,â adding that âa nominee should offer no hints, no forecasts, no views.â Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the committeeâs ranking Democrat, said a dissent from Judge Kavanaugh opened a window on his views on abortion, one she said indicated that he would not support the constitutional right to abortion established in 1973 in Roe v. Wade. Last year, Judge Kavanaugh said that allowing an undocumented teenager in federal custody to obtain an abortion was âbased on a constitutional principle as novel as it is wrong: a new right for unlawful immigrant minors in U.S. government detention to obtain immediate abortion on demand.â He said he would have given the government more time to find a sponsor for the teenager. Advertisement But Judge Kavanaugh did not join a separate dissent from Judge Karen LeCraft Henderson, who wrote that the teenager had no right to an abortion because she was not a citizen and had entered the country unlawfully. Will a Supreme Court with two Trump-appointed justices overrule the right to an abortion? Itâs possible, but not the most likely outcome. Adam Liptak, The Timesâs Supreme Court reporter, explains. Ms. Feinstein is one of the most ardent supporters of gun restrictions in the Senate, and in her opening statement she forecast that she intended to grill Judge Kavanaugh about what she regarded as his âout of the mainstreamâ views on gun rights. Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trumpâs nominee to the Supreme Court, appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee for the first day of his confirmation hearing. She was referring to a dissent Judge Kavanaugh wrote in a case challenging a District of Columbia law that required gun owners to register their weapons, and banned possession of semiautomatic rifles. The appeals court upheld the limits as constitutionally permissible under the Second Amendment. But in his dissent, Judge Kavanaugh argued that a ban on semiautomatic rifles should be unconstitutional because they âhave not traditionally been banned and are in common use by law-abiding citizens for self-defense in the home, hunting and other lawful uses.â For the senator, the issue of gun violence is personal. She became mayor of San Francisco more than 40 years ago when Mayor George Moscone and Harvey Milk, an openly gay politician, were shot and killed. In her opening statement, she noted that President Trump had promised that whomever he nominated to the Supreme Court would be âanti-choice and pro-gun,â adding, âWe believe what he said.â Fred Guttenberg, the father of Jaime Guttenberg, a 14-year-old girl killed in the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting in Parkland, Florida, took to Twitter on Tuesday to say that Mr. Kavanaugh had rebuffed him when he went to introduce himself. 
            Just walked up to Judge Kavanaugh as morning session ended. Put out my hand to introduce myself as Jaime Guttenberg's dad. He pulled his hand back, turned his back to me and walked away. I guess he did not want to deal with the reality of gun violence.         In a video of the hearing, Mr. Guttenberg can be seen approaching the judge as the hearing was breaking for lunch and extending his hand to Judge Kavanaugh. Though it wasnât clear whether Judge Kavanaugh first saw him, the nominee did turn back and look at Mr. Guttenburg, who took a step closer and appeared to say something to him. Judge Kavanaugh then turned and walked away. 
            Video of @fred_guttenberg attempting to introduce himself to Kavanaugh here pic.twitter.com/ywSFbVGQHA  That instance follows Senator Feinsteinâs charge made earlier this morning that Mr. Kavanaughâs view on guns are âfar outside the mainstream.â 
            Fred Guttenberg, the father of Jamie Guttenberg who was killed in the shooting in Parkland, Fla., left, tries to shake hands with @realDonaldTrump's Supreme Court nom., Brett Kavanaugh, right, during a lunch break. Kavanaugh did not shake his hand. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik) @ap pic.twitter.com/smcCGuLT6X  While Republicans cite Judge Kavanaughâs impressive resume â Yale Law degree, Supreme Court clerkship â as a reason to confirm him, Democrats hope to turn the nomineeâs biography against him by portraying him as a partisan hack. Advertisement Before joining the federal appeals court here, Judge Kavanaugh had a long history of Republican political activism. He worked on the team, led by Ken Starr, which investigated former President Bill Clinton. He was in Florida during the presidential recount of 2000, advising then-Gov. George W. Bush. (He also once represented Mr. Bushâs brother Jeb.) Later, he joined the Bush White House. The judge has been involved âof the most pitched and partisan battles of our lifetimes,â Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, said. Addressing Judge Kavanaugh directly, he added that it is âcritical that this committee and the American people fully examine your record to understand what kind of justice you would be.â Senator Durbin, meanwhile, has called Judge Kavanaugh the âForrest Gump of Republican politicsâ â a phrase he reprised on Tuesday, adding, âYou always show up in the picture.â The hits kept coming: âJudge Kavanaugh has been knee deep in partisan politics,â Senator Mazie K. Hirono, Democrat of Hawaii, said. The first day of the confirmation hearings for Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trumpâs nominee to the Supreme Court, started with Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee pushing to adjourn and protesters being removed. Of course, President Trump also had to weigh in. 
            ....looking to inflict pain and embarrassment to one of the most highly renowned jurists to ever appear before Congress. So sad to see!         Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said that Judge Kavanaughâs still-hidden White House records could be particularly illuminating on a question of pressing urgency: understanding his views on the scope of executive power â and, in particular, whether sitting presidents should be immune from legal process, like subpoenas to testify in a criminal investigation â while they are in office. Judge Kavanaugh came up in Washington conservative legal circles as a prosecutor working for Kenneth W. Starrâs independent counsel investigation into President Bill Clinton. But later, in a speech he made at a law school after serving in President George W. Bushâs White House and then becoming a judge, he said that the distraction of preparing for questions by criminal investigators would make a president do a worse job, so presidents should be excused from that burden until after they leave office. Advertisement His remarks were ambiguous: he said Congress should consider enacting a statute granting presidents temporary immunity while in office, which could suggest that the Constitution does not grant presidents that authority on its own. Still, he clearly indicated that he sympathizes with the idea that being subjected to legal process burdens a presidentâs ability to carry out his constitutional responsibilities. And the Supreme Court has never decided whether a president can be forced to testify in response to a subpoena â something that it may address if Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating President Trumpâs campaign ties to Russia, were to subpoena him. Against that backdrop, Mr. Leahy said that Judge Kavanaughâs âexpansive view of executive power and executive immunityâ may have intrigued Mr. Trump, while also noting that the president over the weekend attacked Attorney General Jeff Sessions for permitting the Justice Department to indict two Republican congressmen ahead of the midterm election. âYouâve taken the unorthodox position that presidents should not be burdened with a criminal or civil investigation while in office. Now we have a president who has declared in the last 24 hours that the Department of Justice shouldnât prosecute Republicans,â Mr. Leahy said. âNow, itâs â itâs Alice in Wonderland. And I find it difficult to imagine that your views on this subject escape the attention of President Trump, who seems increasingly fixated on his own ballooning legal jeopardy.â Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, picked up that line of attack, focusing on what he said were convenient inconsistencies in Judge Kavanaughâs views on whether sitting presidents can be questioned in criminal investigations. As a lawyer working for Mr. Starr, Judge Kavanaugh urged his superiors to question Mr. Clinton in graphic detail. After serving as Mr. Bushâs staff secretary, though, Judge Kavanaughâs views evolved. âI believe that the president should be excused from some of the burdens of ordinary citizenship while serving in office,â he wrote in 2009 in the Minnesota Law Review. Among those burdens, Judge Kavanaugh wrote, were responding to civil lawsuits and criminal charges. Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona, can always be counted on to criticize Mr. Trump, and on Tuesday he did not disappoint. Mr. Flake began his opening statement by praising Judge Kavanaugh as a good family man and a fine athlete â the judge runs marathons. But then he pivoted to express serious concerns over how Judge Kavanaugh will deal with a president who does not seem to respect the institutions of government or the rule of law.  Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. After reading aloud Mr. Trumpâs weekend tweet attacking Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Mr. Flake said, âThat is why a lot of people are concerned about this administration and why they want to ensure that our institutions hold.â But while he pledged to question Judge Kavanaugh closely on his view of executive power, Mr. Flake is widely expected to be a yes vote when it comes to the judgeâs confirmation. Advertisement Judge Kavanaughâs nomination has been controversial at his alma mater, Yale Law School, Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, noted. Many hundreds of current and former law students there signed an open letter chastising the law schoolâs administration for issuing a news release noting his nomination and gathering positive comments from faculty members. 
                President Trump is moving quickly to appoint federal judges. So far, his efforts have strengthened conservative majorities rather than changed the balance of most courts.             âJudge Kavanaughâs nomination,â the letter said, âpresents an emergency â for democratic life, for our safety and freedom, for the future of our country.â The law schoolâs news release concerning Judge Kavanaugh was similar to earlier ones issued after other alumni were nominated to high positions, including Justice Sonia Sotomayor and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. A second open letter, also signed by hundreds of current and former students, wrote that Judge Kavanaugh âhas been a valuable friend to the Yale communityâ and was âeminently qualified to serve as a Supreme Court justice.â The moment Judge Kavanaughâs confirmation hearing opened, Democrats and protesters turned it into a verbal brawl. Senator Kamala Harris, Democrat of California, immediately interrupted the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Charles E. Grassley, demanding a delay to consider tens of thousands of pages of documents released Monday â the night before the hearing and a holiday. Other Democrats backed her, especially the senators considering a run for the White House in 2020, as did womenâs rights protesters, several of whom were arrested and thrown out as they decried the sessions as a sham. âWe cannot possibly move forward, Mr. Chairman, with this hearing,â one of the presidential aspirants, Senator Harris, declared. Advertisement Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut called the hearing âa charade and a mockery.â âWhat are we trying to hide? Why are we rushing?â asked Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. As the Democrats spoke, activists were dragged, shouting, one by one out of the hearing room. âWe dissent! Vote no! Vote no!â one cried. [Read more about how the G.O.P. under Trump is carrying out a sweeping transformation of the federal judiciary.] Mr. Grassley argued that the committee has received âmore materials on Judge Kavanaugh than we have had on any Supreme Court nominee in history.â He said Republican aides have already reviewed the 42,000 documents that arrived Monday night. âThatâs no reason to delay the hearing.â Democrats quieted down â temporarily â and the hearing appeared to be getting underway with Judge Kavanaugh introducing his family â including his wife, his parents, an aunt and uncle and cousins. But as soon as he finished, Democrats renewed their request to delay the hearing. The fight over records concerning Judge Kavanaugh came as no surprise to Senate Republicans. Some of them, including Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, feared in July â when President Trump was choosing among the finalists â that Judge Kavanaughâs enormous paper trail could stall his nomination Confirmation hearings for Supreme Court nominees didnât always exist. But the 19th Amendment, school desegregation and television all contributed to major changes in the process. New York Times reporters Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin wrote at the time that Mr. McConnell made clear in multiple phone calls with Mr. Trump and the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, that Judge Kavanaughâs paper trail would pose difficulties for his confirmation. Advertisement Because the number of pages ran into the millions, Mr. McConnell said they could hand Senate Democrats an opportunity to delay the confirmation vote until after the new session of the Supreme Court began in October. Democrats focused intensely on the amount of information they say is being withheld from them about Judge Kavanaughâs work in the White House under President George W. Bush. 
            Itâs unprecedented for the Senate Judiciary Committee to be considering a nominee for the highest court in the land without reviewing documents from 35 months of his public service in the White House. #WhatAreTheyHiding pic.twitter.com/eE7ThqLUZH  Thousands of pages of records have not yet been made public, and on Friday the Trump administration asserted executive privilege and refused to release more than 100,000 pages of records about Judge Kavanaughâs time in the Bush White House. An additional 42,000 pages of documents were released the night before the hearing, according to Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, who raised complaints about the timing. 
             The Senate was just given an additional 42,000 pages of Kavanaugh documents the NIGHT BEFORE his confirmation hearing. This underscores just how absurd this process is. Not a single senator will be able to review these records before tomorrow.         A press officer for the committee, responding via the committeeâs Twitter account a few hours later, said the majority staff had âcompleted its review of each and every one of these pages.â About a dozen women, dressed in red robes and white bonnets in the fashion of âThe Handmaidâs Tale,â stood silently, as if in prayer, outside the hearing room. In the atrium of the Hart Senate Office Building, just off the hearing room, over 250 activists from womenâs rights groups held a vigil in protest, sharing stories underscoring the importance of reproductive rights. They were joined by Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, the New York Democrat, who gave brief remarks, and gave a thunderous cheer when Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, joined them and took pictures with enthralled fans. Inside the chamber, protesters were arrested one by one, leaving once-coveted seats in the hearing room empty. 
            After the arrests at the Kavanaugh Hearing there are plenty of seats open in the hearing room: pic.twitter.com/LV0LC14HEf  The Womenâs March took credit for the protests, and said more than 30 women have been arrested so far. (So have a few men.) Advertisement âWomen are disrupting this hearing today because our lives are at risk,â Rachel OâLeary Carmona, chief operating officer of the Womenâs March, said in an emailed statement. âWomen will die if Kavanaugh is confirmed.â One protester, referencing the withholding of records relating to Judge Kavanaugh, offered what was perhaps the dayâs most unusual shout: âI had to have a background check to work in a laundromat!â For Democrats on the committee with possible presidential aspirations â including Senators Cory Booker of New Jersey, Harris and Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota â the televised hearings offer an opportunity for combative questioning that can fuel both viral clips and material for a 2020 campaign. It is unclear how much Senator Feinstein will attempt to direct the questioning from members of her own party. As the Senateâs most ardent proponent of gun restrictions, she is expected to grill Judge Kavanaugh on a 2009 dissent in which he argued against banning semiautomatic weapons. Ms. Feinstein, who was the chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee when it conducted an investigation into the Bush administrationâs torture program after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, may also pursue her own line of questioning over Judge Kavanaughâs time as an associate White House counsel â especially his offer to help a senior administration official prepare testimony about the governmentâs surveillance of conversations between certain terrorism suspects and their lawyers. That offer, revealed in a trove of documents released ahead of the confirmation hearing, contradicts Judge Kavanaughâs 2006 testimony, in which he told lawmakers he was ânot involved in the questions about the rules governing detention of combatants.â Democrats have charged that the statement, made in a White House email, was a lie, although it is unknown if Judge Kavanaugh actually provided assistance. Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane contributed reporting. Get politics and Washington news updates via Facebook, Twitter and the Morning Briefing newsletter. We’re interested in your feedback on this page. Tell us what you think. Go to Home Page »

author: MICHELLE GOLDBERG
content: It’s fitting that last week’s Kavanaugh confirmation hearings were regularly interrupted by the sound of women screaming. Again and again, protesters, most of them female, cried out for the preservation of their rights, and were arrested. Republican men were … [+1375 chars]
description: A protester dressed as a character from “The Handmaid’s Tale” attended the first day of Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearing last week.
title: The Handmaid’s Court
text: Advertisement Supported by Jane Doe may have been the first pregnant girl Brett Kavanaugh ruled against. But she wonât be the last. By Michelle Goldberg Opinion Columnist Shortly after his inauguration, Donald Trump, uniquely attentive to his debt to the religious right, appointed the anti-abortion activist E. Scott Lloyd to head the Office of Refugee Resettlement, despite Lloydâs lack of relevant experience. The position gave Lloyd authority over unaccompanied minors caught crossing into the United States, authority Lloyd exploited to try to stop pregnant migrants from getting abortions. Last year, thanks to Lloydâs interference, a 17-year-old from Central America had to wage a legal battle to end her pregnancy. Known in court filings as Jane Doe, the girl learned she was pregnant while in custody in Texas, and was adamant that she wanted an abortion. In keeping with Texasâs parental consent law, she obtained a judgeâs permission, helped by a legal organization called Janeâs Due Process. Janeâs Due Process raised money for the abortion, which was scheduled for the end of her first trimester. But under Lloydâs direction, the shelter where she was being detained refused to cooperate. Doe went back to court, and a federal judge ruled in her favor, issuing a temporary restraining order against the government. The administration appealed, and the case, Garza v. Hargan, went to a three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. One of the judges was Brett Kavanaugh. Garza v. Hargan was the only major abortion-rights case Kavanaugh ever ruled on. His handling of it offers a clue about whatâs in store for American women if heâs confirmed to the Supreme Court. No one knows whether Kavanaugh would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade outright or simply gut it. But even on a lower court, Kavanaugh put arbitrary obstacles in the way of someone desperate to end her pregnancy. Thanks to Trump, he may soon be in a position to do the same to millions of others. Itâs fitting that last weekâs Kavanaugh confirmation hearings were regularly interrupted by the sound of women screaming. Again and again, protesters, most of them female, cried out for the preservation of their rights, and were arrested. Republican men were contemptuous. âWhatâs the hysteria coming from?â asked Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska. Let me answer. It is true, as Sasse said, that protesters have claimed for many years that if Roe v. Wade is overturned, women will die. Itâs a fair prediction; women died before Roe, and where abortion is illegal, unsafe abortion leads to maternal death. In the past, however, Roe has been saved. Should Kavanaugh be confirmed, it will either fall or be eviscerated.  In Garza, Kavanaugh and another judge vacated the temporary restraining order that prevented the government from hindering Doeâs abortion. Brigitte Amiri, an A.C.L.U. lawyer who represented the girl, was stunned, because it seemed clear that Doe, whoâd already obtained the necessary judicial signoff, had the law on her side. âIt wasnât what I was expecting from any judge that would have read Roe v. Wade,â Amiri said of the ruling. âConservatives, progressives, anyone.â Indeed, a few days later, the full court reversed the panelâs decision. Kavanaugh, dissenting, wrote that âthe government has permissible interests in favoring fetal life.â By the time Jane Doe got her abortion, she was 15 weeks pregnant and needed a more complicated second-trimester procedure. On Friday, Rochelle Garza, a lawyer who served as Doeâs temporary legal guardian during the proceedings, testified at Kavanaughâs confirmation hearings. âShe was one of the most vulnerable people in our community,â Garza said of the girl, adding, âShe was an immigrant, she didnât speak English, she was in detention, and she was being put under extreme pressure. And I felt it was unfortunate that Judge Kavanaugh did not take that into consideration.â We shouldnât expect a Trump nominee, however personally decent his friends say he is, to care about womenâs wishes. Kavanaughâs defenders insist that heâs the sort of judge any Republican would appoint, and they are correct. Still, itâs a particularly bitter insult that women stand to lose reproductive autonomy thanks to the minority presidential victory of a louche misogynist.  Politicians sometimes say that they are personally opposed to abortion, but believe it should be legal. Trump and some of his enablers reverse that formulation. The president, who does not, according to two of his lovers, wear condoms, has declined to say whether heâs ever been involved with an abortion. According to court papers unsealed on Friday, Elliott Broidy, former deputy finance chairman of the Republican National Committee, also refused to wear condoms during sex with his mistress, Shera Bechard, then demanded she get an abortion when she became pregnant. According to the unsealed papers, Broidy admired Trumpâs âuncanny ability to sexually abuse woman and get away with it.â A famous pro-choice poster from the 1980s proclaimed, âYour body is a battleground.â Kavanaugh is likely to join the Supreme Court because in 2016, the woman whom most women voted for was defeated. Now our bodies are subject to occupation. Michelle Goldberg has been an Opinion columnist since 2017. She is the author of several books about politics, religion and women’s rights, and was part of a team that won a Pulitzer Prize for public service in 2018 for reporting on workplace sexual harassment issues.  @michelleinbklyn  Advertisement

author: DANIEL VICTOR
content: • Modeling in the #TimesUp era New York Fashion Week begins today, and all eyes are on how the industry has adapted after multiple scandals involving sexual assault and harassment. While some attitudes have shifted at the top of the fashion pyramid, change ha… [+1337 chars]
description: President Trump sought to assert command on Wednesday after an unsigned Op-Ed in The Times claimed that “unsung heroes” in the administration were putting country before president.
title: Donald Trump, Brett Kavanaugh, Theranos: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Advertisement Supported by By Daniel Victor  (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) Good morning. Hereâs what you need to know: â¢ Itâs the question almost everyone in Washington (and beyond) wants answered. President Trump erupted in anger on Wednesday after The Times published a stinging Opinion piece by an unidentified senior official saying that a âquiet resistanceâ in the administration was working to thwart the presidentâs âworst inclinations.â The article, which said the presidentâs problems were rooted in âamorality,â raised questions about his capacity to govern. Read the Op-Ed here. Mr. Trump denounced the essay, calling it âgutless,â and the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, issued a statement about its author saying, âThis coward should do the right thing and resign.â Washington has been scrambling to identify the anonymous official. This morning, Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo denied writing the piece. â¢ The Opinion pages of The Times are managed separately from the newsroom. The Op-Ed editor, James Dao, said the material was important enough to merit anonymity, which the department rarely grants. â¢ As a White House lawyer in the George W. Bush administration, Judge Brett Kavanaugh raised doubts about whether Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court ruling that found a constitutional right to an abortion, was âsettled law,â according to an email made available to The Times. He also called an affirmative action regulation âa naked racial set-aside.â The email, written in March 2003, is one of thousands of documents that were turned over to the Senate Judiciary Committee before confirmation hearings for Judge Kavanaugh, President Trumpâs Supreme Court nominee, but that were not made public or available for discussion by Democrats. The document was among several provided to The Times late Wednesday. The news is likely to take center stage today, the third day of Judge Kavanaughâs confirmation hearings. Follow here for live updates. â¢ Testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee  on Wednesday, the Supreme Court nominee dodged questions about presidential powers to thwart the Russia investigation and obstruction of justice. But he avoided any blunders that would damage his standing with Republicans. â¢ Regulation of social media is coming. That was one message lawmakers had for Jack Dorsey, Twitterâs chief executive, and Sheryl Sandberg, Facebookâs chief operating officer, as the two testified on Capitol Hill on Wednesday. âCongress is going to have to take action here,â said Senator Mark Warner, Democrat of Virginia, during hearings about the moderation of online content. âThe era of the Wild West in social media is coming to an end.â â¢ Republicans accused Twitter of being biased against conservatives, a point Mr. Dorsey denied. But he and Ms. Sandberg largely avoided taking sides in highly political debates.  â¢ Britain has charged two Russian intelligence officers with attempted murder after the poisoning in March of a former Russian spy and his daughter in England. Prime Minister Theresa May announced that British intelligence services had identified the men, who used the names Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov, as officers of Russiaâs military intelligence service. âWe decisively reject these insinuations,â Russian officials responded. â¢ British investigators  described a needle-in-a-haystack investigation involving more than 11,000 hours of video from ports, train stations, shop windows, car dashboards and roads. â¢ The Justice Department plans to charge a North Korean spy over the hacking of Sony Pictures Entertainment in 2014, according to three U.S. officials familiar with the indictment. The cyberattack, carried out after Sony produced a comedy portraying the assassination of the North Korean leader, wiped out 70 percent of Sonyâs computers. â¢ Theranos, the Silicon Valley start-up that pledged to revolutionize lab testing to detect diseases, is shutting down. â¢ Warner Brothers and its corporate siblings, HBO and Turner Broadcasting, introduced plans to increase the number of women and people of color involved in their movies and TV shows. â¢ Nikeâs first ad featuring Colin Kaepernick, the former N.F.L. quarterback who led player protests, is set to run tonight on NBC during the leagueâs first regular season game. â¢ U.S. stocks were mixed on Wednesday. Hereâs a snapshot of global markets today. Tips for a more fulfilling life. â¢ Make your iPhone photographs even more beautiful. â¢ Hereâs how to break the taboo on talking about money. â¢ Recipe of the day: Roy Choiâs carne asada is perfect for taco night. â¢ A major victory for gay rights in India  The countryâs Supreme Court struck down a ban on consensual gay sex today, killing one of the oldest laws of its kind in the world. â¢ Where has Steve Perry been? The former Journey frontman who walked away from stardom is returning in October with a solo album, âTraces,â that breaks 20 years of silence. He told us about the personal tragedy that moved him to create music again. â¢ Modeling in the #TimesUp era New York Fashion Week begins today, and all eyes are on how the industry has adapted after multiple scandals involving sexual assault and harassment. While some attitudes have shifted at the top of the fashion pyramid, change hasnât always trickled down. Hereâs more from this weekâs Style section. â¢ When teachers are first responders âTheir PTSD can be as serious as what you see in soldiers,â an expert said of teachers after a school shooting. âBut unlike soldiers, none of them signed up for this, and none of them have been trained to cope with it.â Our Magazine looks at the suffering of public servants accustomed to placing studentsâ needs above their own. â¢ U.S. Open builds to a climax Kei Nishikori and Naomi Osaka became the first Japanese players to reach the semifinals of the same Grand Slam tournament, and Anastasija Sevastova, âa girl from the middle of nowhere,â will face Serena Williams in the last four tonight. Follow our tennis coverage here. â¢ A new J.R.R. Tolkien book debuts on top âThe Fall of Gondolin,â written in 1917 and pieced together by the authorâs son over decades, debuted at No. 1 on our hardcover fiction best-seller list. You can find all of our best-seller lists here. â¢ Best of late-night TV Trevor Noah was unswayed by the argument in the anonymous Times Op-Ed that using the 25th Amendment to remove President Trump would be too messy: âItâs like thereâs a sign that says, âIn case of emergency, break glass,â but then these guys are like, âI mean, we could break the glass, but then there would be glass everywhere.â â â¢ Quotation of the day âI always tell the kids I love them, even if theyâre miserable and cursing me out.â â Rachel Harris, a school safety agent in the Bronx who is part of a pilot program to defuse conflicts. â¢ The Times, in other words Hereâs an image of todayâs front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles. â¢ What weâre reading George Gustines, a senior editor for graphics and video, recommends this Vulture article: âAbraham Riesman offers a thorough summary and timeline about a very angry segment of the comic-book audience. âComicsgate,â he writes, âis a loose confederation of tweeters and YouTubers who make it their business to yell about how much they hate the âsocial justice warriorsâ who are, in their eyes, ruining their favorite medium with leftist politics.â â Hours after losing to Chris Evert in the semifinals of the U.S. Open in 1975, Martina Navratilova sat in a secret meeting with F.B.I. agents, where she declared her intention to defect from Czechoslovakia. âI wanted my freedom,â Ms. Navratilova told reporters at a news conference on this day 43 years ago. She was 18. The Czech tennis federation, under the Communist governmentâs rule, had exerted control over its young starâs schedule, finances and even her playing style. They had threatened to keep her from that yearâs U.S. Open, saying she had become too âAmericanized.â Ms. Navratilova had not yet won any of her 18 Grand Slam singles titles. âI just felt that if I want to become No. 1, which I want to, that I couldnât do it under the circumstances at home,â she told reporters. She became the world No. 1 in 1978, and an American citizen in 1981. Ms. Navratilova was among the first openly gay professional athletes, but she said she waited to become a citizen before coming out, fearing the news might disqualify her. Ms. Navratilova now has dual citizenship, after regaining her Czech nationality in 2008. By then, she had earned 59 Grand Slam doubles and singles titles. Aodhan Beirne wrote todayâs Back Story. _____ Your Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. To receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, sign up here. Check out our full range of free newsletters here. What would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com. Follow Daniel Victor on Twitter: @bydanielvictor. Advertisement

description: Four days of Supreme Court confirmation hearings ended Friday the way they began: With fierce partisan divisions over Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh.
title: As Hearings End, Democrats Accuse Supreme Court Nominee of Dissembling
text: Advertisement Supported by By Charlie Savage and Sheryl Gay Stolberg WASHINGTON â Senate Democrats and their allies accused Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh on Friday of misleading the Judiciary Committee, saying he dissembled in testimony about crucial issues ranging from his views on abortion rights to his involvement in several Bush-era controversies. But Republicans expressed confidence that none of the punches Democrats had thrown at the Supreme Court nominee had landed with sufficient force to jeopardize his confirmation. Four days of Supreme Court confirmation hearings ended on Friday the way they began, with sharply partisan charges and tension remarkable for normally staid proceedings. In two of the strongest statements on Friday, Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the top Democrat on the committee, said on Twitter that Judge Kavanaugh gave answers that âwere not trueâ when asked whether he had used âmaterials stolenâ from committee Democrats when he was a White House lawyer under President George W. Bush. Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, also using Twitter, accused the judge of lying. âWhat else is he lying about?â Mr. Wyden wrote. âHis views on overturning #RoevWade? Whether he was involved in Bush-era torture programs? Whether he believes Trump can pardon himself?â Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, raised the volume on Saturday morning. But Raj Shah, a White House spokesman, dismissed the complaints by Democrats and liberals, while attacking those who made public some of Judge Kavanaughâs White House emails that were provided to the Judiciary Committee but marked âconfidential,â meaning they were not to be disclosed. âWe should put these Democratic senators under oath, because they are the ones deliberately misleading the public,â Mr. Shah said. âTheyâve violated Senate rules, leaked confidential information and trafficked in conspiracy theories â all in a desperate attempt to smear Judge Kavanaughâs stellar reputation. The good news for the country is that it has been a resounding failure.â Mr. Shahâs final point may prove true. Senate Democratic staff members, preparing for the next phase of the fight, circulated a draft document on Friday titled âJudge Kavanaugh Misled the Judiciary in 2004 and 2006 and Has Done So Once Again.â But with no Republican senator signaling any concern, and with the party holding 51 votes in the Senate, Judge Kavanaughâs confirmation appeared likely, even as questions linger over documents that remain hidden from the public. âI expect that over the next months, even years, all of the relevant documents will eventually become public and we may well end up having a much clearer record in a number of the incidents that were debated very fiercely,â said Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware. âAnd at that point,â he added, âJudge Kavanaugh will most likely be serving as a justice of the Supreme Court.â Here are some of the issues that arose during the hearing, and how Judge Kavanaugh addressed them: Mr. Leahy pushed Judge Kavanaugh on his testimony, during his 2004 and 2006 appeals court confirmation hearings, that he neither knew nor suspected that a Republican Senate aide with whom he had interacted, Manuel Miranda, had infiltrated the computer files of Judiciary Committee Democrats about which of Mr. Bushâs appeals court nominees Democrats would try to block and with what tactics. Mr. Leahy cited numerous emails that Mr. Miranda had sent Judge Kavanaugh and a few other officials during that period, including verbatim internal Democratic talking points, a draft Democratic letter that was not yet public, âintelâ about what questions Mr. Leahy was planning to ask a nominee at a coming hearing, and an email chain about meeting at Mr. Mirandaâs apartment to obtain âuseful infoâ about two other Democratic senators. But Judge Kavanaugh testified that none of the information he received had raised a âred flag,â suggesting that he had assumed the Republican Senate aides were instead receiving information from friends on the Democratic staff. Separately, Mr. Miranda told The New York Times that he never informed Judge Kavanaugh about the computer server. âI am not satisfied with the answers, certainly on the stolen Manny Miranda material,â Mr. Leahy said on Friday. âI think itâs fair to say that he was not forthright with me and Iâm bothered by it.â A Democratic lawyer who saw some of her work copied by Mr. Miranda concluded on Slate.com on Friday that Judge Kavanaugh not only should not be confirmed but also should perhaps âbe impeached.â As an appeals court nominee, Judge Kavanaugh distanced himself from significant involvement with two other Bush appeals court nominees who attracted controversy, Charles W. Pickering Sr. and William H. Pryor Jr. While he acknowledged in writing that he had âparticipated in discussions and meetings concerning all of the presidentâs judicial nominationsâ as a member of a judicial selection committee, he told senators that Judge Pryor âwas not one that I worked on personallyâ and Judge Pickering âwas not one of the judicial nominees that I was primarily handling.â Still, emails showed he did do some work on both nominations. Among other things, Judge Kavanaugh was invited to participate in a conference call about Judge Pryorâs pending confirmation hearing in an email that went to a âPryor Working Group,â and he performed a variety of tasks on the Pickering nomination, like meeting with Senate aides about him and handling a draft opinion article that supported Mr. Pickering. A colleague identified him as one of two White House lawyers who had been âmuch more involved in the Pickering fight.â In August, after Democrats suggested that Judge Kavanaugh had misled the Senate about his involvement in the Pickering nomination, his defenders said he was not the White House official assigned to âprimarilyâ handle that one. Asked at the hearing about the Pryor nomination, Mr. Kavanaugh gave a similar answer. Judge Kavanaugh also faced scrutiny from Mr. Leahy over his statement to Mr. Leahy in his 2006 confirmation hearing that he had first learned about the Bush administrationâs warrantless surveillance program from a December 2005 news article. Mr. Leahy had been asking what he had seen in his role as staff secretary from 2003 to 2006. Yet a Sept. 17, 2001, email showed that Judge Kavanaugh â then a White House lawyer, not staff secretary â asked John Yoo, a Justice Department lawyer, whether there were âany results yetâ on the Fourth Amendment implications of warrantless surveillance for counterterrorism purposes. Later that day, Mr. Yoo completed a memo on a âhypotheticalâ warrantless wiretapping program that evolved into a more extensive memo that Mr. Yoo signed on Oct. 4, 2001, the day the program secretly started. Insisting that his testimony had been â100 percent accurate,â Judge Kavanaugh said that in the early days after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, White House lawyers worked on many things related to national security, but he had never been âread intoâ the existence of the surveillance program. Mr. Yoo corroborated that account. Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, grilled Judge Kavanaugh about his testimony over his involvement in Bush administration policy for the handling of captured terrorism suspects. As an appeals court nominee, Judge Kavanaugh turned aside questions about torture by saying that he was ânot involved in the questions about the rules governing detention of combatantsâ and portrayed his portfolio as focusing on âcivil justice issuesâ like terrorism insurance. It later emerged that when the Bush administration was internally debating whether American citizens being held as âenemy combatantsâ should have access to lawyers, Judge Kavanaugh had advised that the Supreme Court justice Anthony M. Kennedy would probably rule that they had a right to them. An email also showed that in September 2001, he volunteered to prepare a senior Bush administration official to testify about the governmentâs monitoring of conversations between federal terrorism inmates and their lawyers. But Judge Kavanaugh said that âmy testimony then was accurate and was the truth.â He said he had understood Mr. Durbinâs question in 2006 to be about the Bush administrationâs âenhanced interrogation program,â which he was not involved in. As for the signing statement about the torture ban, he said his role as staff secretary was to hand papers to the president that had been prepared by others. On Wednesday, Judge Kavanaugh told Ms. Feinstein that he considered the 1972 abortion rights ruling, Roe v. Wade, to be a âsettled as a precedent of the Supreme Court entitled the respect under principlesâ of a legal doctrine that justices should not lightly reopen already decided issues. But a 2003 White House email by Judge Kavanaugh â which emerged into public view on Thursday morning â showed that he had objected to a line in a draft opinion article stating that âit is widely accepted by legal scholars across the board that Roe v. Wade and its progeny are the settled law of the land.â He proposed deleting that line, writing: âI am not sure that all legal scholars refer to Roe as the settled law of the land at the Supreme Court level since court can always overrule its precedent, and three current justices on the court would do so.â Although his email stopped short of saying what he personally believed, Democrats and abortion rights advocates portrayed that as a contradiction that suggested he was being evasive and did not believe Roe was settled. But Judge Kavanaugh told Ms. Feinstein on Thursday that he had only meant that the line inaccurately overstated the position âof legal scholarsâ and reiterated that Roe was a precedent that had been reaffirmed repeatedly. On Twitter, follow Charlie Savage @charlie_savage and Sheryl Gay Stolberg @SherylNYT.     Advertisement

author: DAVID LEONHARDT
content: “This is not the debate Republicans wanted to have,” James Wallner, a former Republican Senate staff member, tweeted yesterday morning. “Note: Kavanaugh hasn’t been debated once. It’s just the process, the documents. Democrats have framed this debate 100%.” A… [+1362 chars]
description: Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, center, at his Senate confirmation hearing in Washington, D.C. For the most part, the day wasn’t about him.
title: The Meaning of a Raucous Supreme Court Hearing
text: Advertisement Supported by Also: Trump's own aides disdain him. Itâs shocking but no longer surprising. By David Leonhardt Opinion Columnist First, the revelations about the Trump White House in Bob Woodwardâs forthcoming book are shocking. Many White House officials do not respect the president, and theyâre quite happy to leak damaging anecdotes about him. For anyone who spent time in Washington during the Bush and Obama years â when both presidents were largely revered by their staffs â itâs a jarring change.  But it is no longer surprising. Itâs been abundantly clear for a long time that President Trump is unfit for the office â and that the people who work for him somehow manage both to disdain him and to continue protecting him at the expense of the country. For more, read The Washington Postâs summary of the book and Jonathan Chaitâs commentary about it for New York magazine.  The Supreme Court. The raucous opening day of Judge Brett Kavanaughâs confirmation hearing wasnât, for the most part, about him. It was about the Republican Partyâs hardball, rule-changing tactics in transforming the federal courts.  âDemocrats are driving home that Republicans keep changing the rules,â Voxâs Tara Golshan wrote. In particular, Democrats yesterday were blasting the last-minute release â without time for scrutiny â of tens of thousands of documents related to Kavanaughâs time as a White House aide during George W. Bushâs presidency.  âThis is not the debate Republicans wanted to have,â James Wallner, a former Republican Senate staff member, tweeted yesterday morning. âNote: Kavanaugh hasnât been debated once. Itâs just the process, the documents. Democrats have framed this debate 100%.â A little history is useful here. Both parties, without question, have played a role in making the courts more partisan and overtly political. As Republicans like to emphasize, the Democrats were the ones who first rejected a nominee based strictly on ideology: Robert Bork, in 1987. In Borkâs place, President Ronald Reagan ultimately nominated the more moderate Anthony Kennedy, whose retirement in turn led to Kavanaughâs nomination. But itâs also the case that Republicans have done much more than Democrats to politicize the courts. How so? One, they have rejected a significantly higher percentage of Democratic nominees since 1981 than Democrats have rejected Republican nominees, according to data collected by the legal scholar Russell Wheeler. This high rejection rate eventually led Senate Democrats during the Obama years to eliminate the filibuster for federal appeals court judges. (That move has recently received criticism, because Republicans later did the same for Supreme Court nominees, but I still think Democrats had no better alternative, given Republican obstruction.) Two, Republicans have nominated more politically extreme judges than Democrats have, as research by Lee Epstein of Washington University and others has shown. Jason Zengerleâs recent Times Magazine piece and the accompanying episode of The Daily podcast have more details. Three, Republicans stole a Supreme Court seat by refusing to let President Barack Obama fill a vacancy in 2016. There was no precedent for such a move, and it was vastly more radical than anything Democrats have done. The seat effectively decided many of the courtâs biggest cases last year, and it will shape the court for decades. As Iâve written before, I expect the Senate to confirm Kavanaugh. Republicans have the votes to do so, and theyâve shown no signs of splintering. If Iâm right about that, this weekâs hearings are more about framing the debate over the future of the courts than anything else.  And Democrats are absolutely right to use the occasion to explain how radical Senate Republicans â and, by extension, large parts of the federal judiciary â have become.  Finally, Congressional districts change over the years. But the closest thing to todayâs Seventh Congressional District in Massachusetts was previously represented by John F. Kennedy, Tip OâNeill and Joe Kennedy II.  Starting in January, it will almost certainly be represented by Ayanna Pressley, who beat the incumbent handily in the Democratic primary last night. She would be the first African-American ever to represent Massachusetts in the House.  You can join me on Twitter (@DLeonhardt) and Facebook. You can subscribe to this newsletter here. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTOpinion). David Leonhardt is a former Washington bureau chief for the Times, and was the founding editor of The Upshot and head of The 2020 Project, on the future of the Times newsroom. He won the 2011 Pulitzer Prize for commentary, for columns on the financial crisis.  @DLeonhardt â¢ Facebook  Advertisement
