description: Senator Charles E. Grassley swearing in the Supreme Court nominee Brett M. Kavanaugh during his confirmation hearing on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
title: Democrats Open Contentious Hearings With Attack on ‘Partisan’ Kavanaugh
text: Advertisement Supported by By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Adam Liptak WASHINGTON â Senate Democrats tore into President Trumpâs Supreme Court nominee on Tuesday, painting Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh as a narrow-minded partisan as the opening day of his confirmation hearings verged on pandemonium. Dozens of screaming protesters were hauled out of the hearing room in handcuffs. The verbal brawl began moments after the hearings began. Democrats, furious at being denied access to records related to Judge Kavanaugh, immediately interrupted the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, demanding time to consider tens of thousands of pages of documents released late Monday â the night before the hearing. Judge Kavanaugh, who finally had the microphone hours later, portrayed himself as an impartial jurist and affable family man. âI am not a pro-plaintiff or pro-defendant judge,â Judge Kavanaugh told the committee. âIâm not a pro-prosecution or pro-defense judge. I am a pro-law judge.â But the hearings were dominated by Democratic theatrics and crackling protests. For more than an hour at the outset, irate Democrats and a frustrated Mr. Grassley parried back and forth. Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, denounced the hearing as âa charade and a mockeryâ and repeatedly moved to adjourn, while Mr. Grassley ruled him out of order over and over again. At one point, Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, accused Democrats of engaging in âmob rule.â Protesters, most of them women, shouted down senators; by dayâs end, Capitol Police said a total of 70 people had been arrested, including nine outside the room. It was a chaotic start to what would ordinarily be a staid, albeit deeply consequential, process. And barring an astounding revelation, the path remains clear for Judge Kavanaughâs ultimate confirmation â probably this month. If he is confirmed, he could shape American jurisprudence for decades to come, replacing the retired Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, a critical swing vote on divisive matters like same-sex marriage and abortion, with an unabashed conservative. The session, which mostly settled down by the afternoon, also gave Americans their first extended glimpse of Judge Kavanaugh, 53, who brought his family â his wife and two daughters, his parents, an aunt and uncle and some cousins â along with him. He talked about going to ball games with his father and coaching his daughter in basketball, drawing bipartisan smiles when he gave a shoutout to each member of the team. But that was about the extent of the comity; just days after members of the Senate had gathered together in a bipartisan show of civility at the funeral of Senator John McCain, the crowded hearing room in the Hart Senate Office Building seethed with antipathy. Some of it reflected lingering bitterness over the treatment of Judge Merrick B. Garland, whose nomination to the Supreme Court in 2016 by President Barack Obama was not even considered by Senate Republicans. In his opening statement, Judge Kavanaugh made a point of praising his colleagues on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit â and one in particular. âI have served with 17 other judges, each of them a colleague and a friend, on a court now led by our superb chief judge, Merrick Garland,â Judge Kavanaugh said While Republicans cited Judge Kavanaughâs impressive rÃ©sumÃ© â Yale Law degree, Supreme Court clerkship â as a reason to confirm him, Democrats made clear that they are laying the groundwork to turn the nomineeâs biography against him. Before joining the federal appeals court, Judge Kavanaugh had a long history of Republican political activism. He worked on the team, led by Ken Starr, that investigated former President Bill Clinton. He was in Florida during the presidential recount of 2000, advising George W. Bush, the governor at the time. (He also once represented Mr. Bushâs brother Jeb.) Later, he joined the Bush White House. âJudge Kavanaugh has been knee deep in partisan politics,â said Senator Mazie K. Hirono, Democrat of Hawaii. Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, said the nominee had been involved in some of âof the most pitched and partisan battles of our lifetimes.â Addressing Judge Kavanaugh directly, Mr. Coons added that it was âcritical that this committee and the American people fully examine your record to understand what kind of justice you would be.â Democrats have been complaining for weeks that the document production process, supervised by a lawyer for former President Bush, is rigged. Only a portion of documents relating to Judge Kavanaughâs time in the White House Counselâs Office have been made available to the committee â and many of those are being kept from the public. And the committee has received no documents from Judge Kavanaughâs time as staff secretary to Mr. Bush, a role that he has said was âthe most interesting and informative for me,â as preparations for his work as a judge. Republicans countered that Democrats were harping on access to documents because they could not quibble with Judge Kavanaughâs qualifications. And they took digs at their Democratic colleagues on the judiciary panel, several of whom â Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, Cory Booker of New Jersey and Kamala D. Harris of California â are weighing presidential runs. âThis is not about documents,â said Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas. âItâs not about qualification. Itâs not about record. What it is about is politics. It is about Democratic senators trying to re-litigate the 2016 election, and, just as importantly, working to begin litigating the 2020 presidential election.â Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said that Judge Kavanaughâs still-hidden White House records could be particularly illuminating on a question of pressing urgency: understanding his views on the scope of executive power â in particular, whether sitting presidents should be immune from the legal process, like subpoenas to testify in a criminal investigation. As a lawyer working for Mr. Starr, Judge Kavanaugh urged his superiors to question Mr. Clinton in graphic detail. But his views on the topic have evolved considerably since then. In a speech he made at a law school after serving in the Bush White House and then becoming a judge, he said that the distraction of preparing for questions by criminal investigators would make a president do a worse job, so presidents should be excused from that burden until after they leave office. Democrats insinuated that Mr. Trump nominated Judge Kavanaugh because he believed the judge would protect him from the investigation being conducted by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel. âYouâve taken the unorthodox position that presidents should not be burdened with a criminal or civil investigation while in office,â Mr. Leahy said. âNow we have a president who has declared in the last 24 hours that the Department of Justice shouldnât prosecute Republicans,â Mr. Leahy said. âNow, itâs â itâs Alice in Wonderland. And I find it difficult to imagine that your views on this subject escape the attention of President Trump, who seems increasingly fixated on his own ballooning legal jeopardy.â Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, picked up that line of attack, focusing on what he said were convenient inconsistencies in Judge Kavanaughâs views on whether sitting presidents could be questioned in criminal investigations. âThis is a president whoâs shown us consistently that heâs contemptuous of the rule of law,â Mr. Durbin said. âItâs that president whoâs decided you are his man.â âSo are people nervous about this?â Mr. Durbin continued. âAre they concerned about it? Of course they are.â Many of those who are nervous were seated in the audience, including Linda Sarsour, a founder of the Womenâs March, who was one of the first in line to attend the hearing â and one of the first to be arrested. Also in the room was Fred Guttenberg, the father of Jaime Guttenberg, a 14-year-old girl killed in the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., who created a buzz on Twitter after Judge Kavanaugh appeared to rebuff his effort to shake the nomineeâs hand. Tuesdayâs hearings consisted of only opening statements. When questioning begins on Wednesday, Judge Kavanaugh is sure to face a detailed examination of his views on abortion. Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, expressed concern that Judge Kavanaugh would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that established a constitutional right to abortion. She cited a dissent last year in which Judge Kavanaugh said he would have delayed an abortion sought by an undocumented teenager in government custody. Judge Kavanaugh said that allowing an undocumented teenager in federal custody to obtain an abortion was âbased on a constitutional principle as novel as it is wrong: a new right for unlawful immigrant minors in U.S. government detention to obtain immediate abortion on demand.â He said he would have given the government more time to find a sponsor for the teenager. In his opening statement, Judge Kavanaugh said he would model himself on Justice Kennedy, for whom he once served as a law clerk. In the process, Judge Kavanaugh sought to assure the committee that he would be âa neutral and impartial arbiter who favors no litigant or policy.â âAs Justice Kennedy showed us, a judge must be independent, not swayed by public pressure,â Judge Kavanaugh said. âOur independent judiciary is the crown jewel of our constitutional republic. In our independent judiciary, the Supreme Court is the last line of defense for the separation of powers, and the rights and liberties guaranteed by the Constitution.â An earlier version of this article misstated the proportion of documents from Judge Brett Kavanaughâs time in the White House Counselâs Office that have been made available to the Senate Judiciary Committee. The committee was given 445,000 of 663,000 total documents, which is a portion but not a small portion of the total. Charlie Savage and Catie Edmondson contributed reporting. Get politics and Washington news updates via Facebook, Twitter and the Morning Briefing newsletter.   Advertisement

author: JOUMANA KHATIB and MERRILL D. OLIVER
content: 5. Alex Jones is facing a reckoning. After news that Twitter had permanently banned his personal account and that of Infowars, his company, the big question is whether his hallmark bluster can see him out of his current peril. With tech giants — including Fac… [+304 chars]
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
title: Brett Kavanaugh, George Papadopoulos, Elon Musk: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: Advertisement Supported by By Joumana Khatib and Merrill D. Oliver (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) Good evening. Hereâs the latest. 1. President Trump called on the Justice Department to investigate who wrote an anonymous Op-Ed in The New York Times assailing his administration. âI would say Jeff should be investigating who the author of that piece was because I really believe itâs national security,â he said on Air Force One, referring to Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Separately, George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign adviser who last year pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I., was sentenced to 14 days in jail. _____ 2. Despite President Trumpâs rage, this week illustrated why almost all elected Republicans have quietly supported him through his travails â or at least not chastised him too loudly. As the confirmation hearings for Judge Brett Kavanaugh came to a close, Senate Republicans pressed steadily through angry liberal protests and sharp questions fromDemocrats. It may deliver one of the Trump administrationâs most enduring legacies: an ideological shift in the Supreme Court that will last for decades. Above, Senator Charles Grassley, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. For an idea of what abortion rights may look like if Judge Kavanaugh joins the Supreme Court, our reporter writes, just look to Arkansas. _____ 3. The U.S. added 201,000 jobs last month, slightly topping analystsâ expectations. The unemployment rate stayed at 3.9 percent, but a 0.4 percent monthly increase in average hourly earnings relieved some of the anxiety about sluggish wages. President Trump escalated the trade dispute with China, threatening to tax virtually all Chinese imports. But so far, political intrigue and anxieties over a trade war have done little to dent a 95-month streak of job creation. _____ 4. More turbulence at Tesla. Shares dropped sharply after news that its accounting chief had departed just weeks after joining the company. The departure is the latest in a string of nearly a dozen top executives who have left Tesla this year. Hours earlier, Teslaâs chief executive, Elon Musk, appeared live on YouTube in an interview with the comedian Joe Rogan and seemed to be smoking marijuana. Mr. Muskâs stability and managerial fitness have come under scrutiny after he unexpectedly tweeted he planned to take the company private, then reversed course. _____ 5. Alex Jones is facing a reckoning. After news that Twitter had permanently banned his personal account and that of Infowars, his company, the big question is whether his hallmark bluster can see him out of his current peril. With tech giants â including Facebook, Pinterest, YouTube and Apple â cracking down on him, Mr. Jonesâs ability to reach his audience has been cut off. But heâs as much marketer as ideological warrior, selling products to assuage the fears he is so expert at stoking. And true to form, heâs been using the challenge to move more product. _____ 6. The E.P.A. is reviewing a major law that restricts mercury emissions by coal-burning power plants. The rule, based on decades of research showing that mercury damages the brain, lungs and fetal health, is among the agencyâs costliest but most effective clean-air policies. The re-evaluation fits into a far-reaching administration strategy to loosen environmental rules affecting countless other industries for years to come by adjusting the factors used to judge the benefits to human health that the rule has brought. _____ 7. The latest from the U.S. Open: Rafael Nadal, the No. 1 seed and defending champion, struggled with a sore knee and ended up retiring from his semifinal against No. 3 Juan MartÃ­n del Potro. Novak Djokovic and 21st-seeded Kei Nishikori are vying for the chance to face Del Potro Sunday afternoon. He will be playing his first Grand Slam final since beating Roger Federer to win the U.S. Open in 2009. And Serena Williams will play Naomi Osaka on Saturday. Ms. Williams will be trying to tie Margaret Courtâs record of 24 major singles titles, while Ms. Osaka will be aiming to duplicate a win this spring over Ms. Williams and claim her first Grand Slam title. Check back for updates and results. _____ 8. Voters in Sweden  head to the polls on Sunday, and immigration and crime have taken center stage. The far right is expected to take one-fifth of the vote, and some Swedes worry that one such party is becoming normalized. âThat gives a playground for the real Nazi parties to play and get more ground,â one man said. âItâs like people have forgotten history. How did Hitler come to power? He started out as a nice guy looking out for the working class.â And a researcher found that in Germany, YouTubeâs recommendation system had steered viewers to fringe and conspiracy videos on a neo-Nazi demonstration. Activists say this may have contributed to a flood of misinformation, helping extremists shape public perceptions even after they had been run off the streets. _____ 9. Good news for late risers in California: The school day could start a little later. Gov. Jerry Brown is weighing a bill that would push back many schoolsâ start time to 8:30 a.m., a change that some say could go a long way toward helping students learn. This weekâs Magazine is devoted to education, with stories about educators across the country who take second jobs to support themselves, a debate over what teachers can say in the classroom and a question of whether good teaching can be taught. _____ 10. Finally, this is your periodic reminder that itâs not all bad news out there. This is the Week in Good News, featuring environmentally friendly Legos, above; a flourishing newspaper that serves retirees; and digital Braille. Have a great weekend. _____ Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern. And donât miss Your Morning Briefing. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. Want to catch up on past briefings? You can browse them here. What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com. Advertisement

author: MICHELLE GOLDBERG
content: Kavanaugh denies the allegation unequivocally; on Monday he said he’s willing to rebut it before the Senate Judiciary Committee. (Judge, who wrote a memoir of his teenage alcoholism, has veered between denying the incident and saying he doesn’t recall it.) Bu… [+2743 chars]
description: Brett Kavanaugh on the third day of his confirmation hearing.
title: Boys Will Be Supreme Court Justices
text: Advertisement Supported by Kavanaughâs accuser is credible. Will it matter? By Michelle Goldberg Opinion Columnist Obviously, I believe Christine Blasey Ford, the psychology professor who says that Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her in high school while his friend Mark Judge watched and, at moments, egged him on. I believe her when she says that Kavanaugh, who she says was drunk, held her down, covered her mouth when she tried to scream, and ground against her while attempting to pull her clothes off. I believe her when she says this incident haunted her all her life. Thereâs rarely hard evidence in a case like this, but Blasey â the surname she prefers to use publicly â has done everything possible to substantiate her claim. Speaking to The Washington Post, she produced notes from a therapist she saw in 2012, whom sheâd told about being attacked by students âfrom an elitist boysâ schoolâ who grew up to become âhigh-ranking members of society in Washington.â According to her husband, that year she identified Kavanaugh to him by name. When Kavanaugh appeared on a shortlist of potential Supreme Court picks â but before his nomination had been announced â Blasey contacted both The Post and her member of Congress, Anna G. Eshoo of California. By all indications, she wanted to head his nomination off without being forced into the spotlight. Blasey passed a polygraph administered by a former F.B.I. agent. The utility of polygraphs is dubious, but her willingness to take one is evidence of her sincerity. According to Axios, some Republicans wanted to call on Blasey to testify publicly, assuming sheâd decline. But on Monday morning, Blaseyâs lawyer, Debra Katz, said that her client is willing to appear before Congress. Kavanaugh denies the allegation unequivocally; on Monday he said heâs willing to rebut it before the Senate Judiciary Committee. (Judge, who wrote a memoir of his teenage alcoholism, has veered between denying the incident and saying he doesnât recall it.) But itâs a sign of how credible Blasey seems that, since this story broke, much of the public debate has been less about whether her accusations are true than whether they are relevant. Some conservatives â though not just conservatives â insist that it is unfair to judge a middle-aged man for things he did as a kid. On Fox News, the former George W. Bush press secretary Ari Fleischer pondered the weight of high school misbehavior. âShould that deny us chances later in life?â he asked. âEven for Supreme Court job, a presidency of the United States, or you name it?â Such arguments would be more convincing if people on the right werenât so selective in their indulgence. Donald Trump called for the death penalty for the Central Park Five, who were 14 to 16 years old when they were arrested. (Theyâve since been proven innocent.) Children are regularly put on sex offender registries, sometimes for their entire lives, for conduct less serious than what Kavanaugh is accused of. In a sour irony, some legal experts think Kavanaughâs confirmation could imperil Miller v. Alabama, a 2012 decision banning life sentences without parole for most teenage convicts. Anyway, this is no longer just about what Kavanaugh might have done 36 years ago. We need to determine, as best we can, if heâs lying now. The Judiciary Committee will be able to begin trying to do that at a public hearing next Monday â called by the committee's head, Charles Grassley, under pressure from some members of his own party. Senators should also demand that Kavanaughâs old friend Judge, who grew up to become a right-wing writer, testify, though Kavanaugh would surely prefer other character witnesses. (âOh for the days when President George W. Bush gave his wife, Laura, a loving but firm pat on the backside in public,â Judge once wrote. âThe man knew who was boss.â) There is a small, dark part of me that thinks it would be fitting if Republicans shove Kavanaugh through despite the allegations against him. Anyone Trump nominates is going to threaten Roe v. Wade. Kavanaugh would at least make plain the power dynamics behind forced pregnancy. We would lose Roe because a president who boasted of sexual assault, elected against the wishes of the majority of female voters, was able to give a lifetime Supreme Court appointment to an ex-frat boy credibly accused of attempted rape. Kavanaugh, helped by an all-male Republican caucus on the Judiciary Committee, would join Clarence Thomas, whose confirmation hearing helped make the phrase âsexual harassmentâ a household term. They and three other men would likely vote against the courtâs three women. The brute imposition of patriarchy would be undeniable. If the Kavanaugh nomination is scuttled, chances are Republicans will try to replace him with someone like Amy Coney Barrett, who is in some ways more conservative. She would put a softer, female face on the culture war. But thatâs a fight for another day. On Sunday, Politico quoted a lawyer close to the White House as saying that the administration had redoubled its support for Kavanaugh in light of Blaseyâs claims: âIf somebody can be brought down by accusations like this, then you, me, every man certainly should be worried.â If the Kavanaugh nomination goes forward, itâs because Trump and his allies believe that a certain class of men accused of sexual assault deserve impunity. The question now is whether any Republican senators believe otherwise. Michelle Goldberg has been an Opinion columnist since 2017. She is the author of several books about politics, religion and women’s rights, and was part of a team that won a Pulitzer Prize for public service in 2018 for reporting on workplace sexual harassment issues.  @michelleinbklyn  Advertisement

author: DANIEL VICTOR
content: David Remnick, the magazine’s editor, initially defended Mr. Bannon’s participation, but he reconsidered after the withdrawals and a furor on social media. • Mr. Bannon called Mr. Remnick “gutless.” A final holdout in Syria • A looming assault on Idlib Provin… [+1281 chars]
description: Rebel soldiers in Idlib Province on Monday. The warring sides in Syria’s merciless civil war are preparing for another brutal offensive, and this one may be the last.
title: Brett Kavanaugh, Jeff Sessions, Colin Kaepernick: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Advertisement Supported by By Daniel Victor  (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) Good morning. Hereâs what you need to know: Judge Brett Kavanaughâs nomination has come to symbolize Republicansâ yearning to shape the future of the federal judiciary. His confirmation hearings begin today, and you can keep up with developments here. A conservative stalwart who would replace the courtâs swing vote, Judge Kavanaugh, 53, would probably tilt the court to the right. We look at his likely role as a justice, and  where he stands on major issues. â¢ Opponents will probably present the judge as a far-right extremist who would roll back abortion rights and protect President Trump from the threat of subpoena. Democrats have already protested the White Houseâs decision to withhold 100,000 pages of documents related to his work in the George W. Bush administration. âTwo easy wins now in doubt because there is not enough time. Good job Jeff.â That was President Trumpâs latest salvo against his attorney general, criticizing the Justice Departmentâs decision to bring criminal charges against two Republican congressmen before the midterm elections. In tying law enforcement decisions to Republicansâ chances to keep control of the House, Mr. Trump drew rebukes from former prosecutors and members of his own party. â¢ Separately, we look at how the Justice Department has redefined decades of civil rights enforcement to focus on protecting people of faith, police officers and local government officials. The magazine decided to withdraw an invitation to President Trumpâs former chief strategist to speak at this yearâs New Yorker Festival after several others said they would drop out in protest. âI will not take part in an event that normalizes hate,â the filmmaker Judd Apatow said. David Remnick, the magazineâs editor, initially defended Mr. Bannonâs participation, but he reconsidered after the withdrawals and a furor on social media. â¢ Mr. Bannon called Mr. Remnick âgutless.â A looming assault on Idlib Province could deliver a decisive military blow against rebel fighters, prompting Western leaders to warn of an impending humanitarian calamity. âAttacking the whole of Idlib to eliminate some radical groups would mean causing the death of hundreds of thousands of people and making 3.5 million people leave their homes one more time,â Mevlut Cavusoglu, Turkeyâs foreign minister, said. â¢ About 30,000 rebels are believed to be in the area, along with millions of noncombatants. A year after the storm, progress in Texas is unevenly distributed, leaving many minority and low-income residents struggling. Our Houston bureau chief and a photographer look at those left behind. A recent survey showed that 27 percent of Hispanic Texans whose homes were badly damaged reported that those homes remained unsafe to live in, compared with 20 percent of blacks and 11 percent of whites. â¢ The Times Magazine also looked in detail at one family, tracing exactly what went wrong with response plans and communications networks. â¢  Americans have started shopping in stores again. But in a broad reordering of the $3.5 trillion retail industry, the companies that learned how to match the instant gratification of e-commerce are capturing more gains. â¢ Amazon, which dominates online retail, is quickly gathering momentum in the $88 billion online ad market. â¢ The chairman of NBC News defended the networkâs handling of Ronan Farrowâs reporting on Harvey Weinstein last year, saying the work was not âfit for broadcast.â Mr. Farrow and one of his sources pushed back. â¢ The U.S.  is making it harder to hire foreigners by denying visas, asking for more information and delaying approvals, say corporate leaders who complain that harsher policies are inhibiting business. â¢ U.S. markets were closed on Monday for Labor Day. Hereâs a snapshot of global markets today. Tips for a more fulfilling life. â¢ Protect your cellphone and data when you travel. â¢ Good apps for managing your money. â¢ Recipe of the day: Try a vegan dinner of Thai curry vegetables. â¢ Senator John McCain was buried at the Naval Academy Cemetery, after a funeral in which two former presidents gave eulogies. â¢ The National Museum of Brazil, already in disrepair, was gutted by fire. We looked at some of the  20 million items that may have been lost. â¢ A judge in Myanmar sentenced two Reuters journalists who had reported on the Rohingya genocide to seven years in prison for violating the Official Secrets Act, despite police testimony that they had been set up. â¢ The father of Mollie Tibbetts, an Iowa college student, asked that her death not be used to advance âviews she believed were profoundly racist.â An undocumented immigrant is a suspect in her killing. â¢ A new face for Nike Colin Kaepernick, the former N.F.L. quarterback who led player protests, is to take part in a âJust Do Itâ campaign. â¢ Stealth assaults Microwave weapons, causing sonic delusions and brain damage, could be behind baffling attacks on American diplomats and family members in Cuba and China, specialists say. Hereâs more from this weekâs Science section. â¢ Francis embraces silence The pope has ignored the growing clamor for him to address allegations that he covered up sexual abuse. âThe truth is humble, the truth is silent,â he said in a homily at the Vatican. â¢ Colonizing Rome Thousands of sea gulls have taken over the Italian capital, invading homes, disrupting concerts and targeting the Vaticanâs peace doves. Thereâs also the stench. â¢ The âoutrage machineâ Our film critic A.O. Scott wraps up the Telluride Film Festival in Colorado, beginning with the partisan howling prompted because Neil Armstrong (played by Ryan Gosling) isnât shown planting the American flag on the moon in âFirst Man.â â¢ Advantage, height Shorter players in tennis have been forced to hone their games to compete with taller rivals. (Hereâs our latest coverage of the U.S. Open, including John Millmanâs upset of Roger Federer.) â¢ Quotation of the day âItâs a moment of intense pain. We can only hope to recover our history from the ashes. Now, we cry and get to work.â â Maurilio Oliveira, a paleoartist at the National Museum of Brazil, which burned down Sunday night. â¢ The Times, in other words Hereâs an image of todayâs front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles. â¢ What weâre reading Michael Roston, an editor for science, recommends this article in The Atlantic: âVice President Mike Pence plays a central role in the Trump administrationâs plans for NASA, the Space Force and business in orbit. He also invokes religious themes in speeches about space. Itâs not new â this writer, Marina Koren, finds religious themes throughout the existence of the space program.â As the country mourns the loss of Senator John McCain, thereâs a story from his past worth mentioning. A sensationalist Russian tabloid published a report in 2008 that purported to explain Mr. McCainâs antipathy to Russia. A government-funded Russian newspaper helped disseminate the story, in which Yuri Truschechkin, a former Soviet lieutenant colonel, said he had shot down Mr. McCainâs plane in North Vietnam in 1967. Mr. McCain spent more than five years as a prisoner of war. Mr. Truschechkin came forward, according to the report, after recognizing Mr. McCain during coverage of his presidential campaign. âHe always hated the Russians,â Mr. Truschechkin said. âHe knew that it was our rocket that downed his plane.â (Watch the video coverage.) Mr. Truschechkin, 70, had led a less than illustrious life, and was surviving on a pension of just over $450 a month. The story prompted some Russians to call for him to be honored. Just two months later, Russian newspapers reported that Mr. Truschechkin had died of cancer. He was said to have had just one question for Mr. McCain: whether he had finished reading the works of Karl Marx. Alisha Haridasani Gupta wrote todayâs Back Story. _____ Your Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here. Check out our full range of free newsletters here. What would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com. Follow Daniel Victor on Twitter: @bydanielvictor. Advertisement

author: DANIEL VICTOR
content: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Pandemonium, protesters and partisanship • Battle lines have been drawn in Supreme Court confirmation hearings. Listen on a computer, an iOS device or an Android device. Tech giants on Capitol Hill Executives from Facebook and Twitter w… [+1195 chars]
description: Ayanna Pressley with supporters in Dorchester, Mass., after her victory on Tuesday. “It seems like change is on the way,” she said.
title: Brett Kavanaugh, Bob Woodward, Amazon: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Advertisement Supported by By Daniel Victor  (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) Good morning. Hereâs what you need to know: Ayanna Pressley upset the 10-term Representative Michael Capuano in a Massachusetts primary on Tuesday, becoming the latest Democratic underdog to ride a restless political climate to victory. Much like the win of Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez in New York, Ms. Pressleyâs success delivered a message to the Democratic establishment that progressive newcomers, especially women and minorities, were unwilling to wait their turn. Her campaign slogan: âChange canât wait.â No Republican is on the November ballot to oppose Ms. Pressley, who would be the stateâs first African-American woman in Congress. â¢ In Chicago, Mayor Rahm Emanuel announced that he would not seek re-election after nearly eight years in office. No clear front-runner has emerged to replace him. Senators will get their first chance to question Judge Brett Kavanaugh under oath about his record and legal opinions today. Abortion, gun rights and the scope of executive power are likely to come up â and our Politics section will have updates from 7 a.m. Eastern. The first day of the confirmation process for the Supreme Court, normally a contentious but decorous affair, verged on pandemonium on Tuesday. Here are the takeaways. Democrats repeatedly interrupted the Senate Judiciary Committee chairman, Charles Grassley of Iowa, demanding time to review documents released the night before. Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, denounced the hearing as âa charade and a mockery.â Dozens of protesters were led out in handcuffs. â¢ Judge Kavanaugh described himself as impartial and âpro-law.â Democrats portrayed him as a narrow-minded conservative partisan. Executives from Facebook and Twitter will testify today about their response to foreign interference in elections and their moderation practices. Theyâre expected to take a conciliatory approach, but it remains to be seen how theyâll respond to accusations of bias. Hereâs what to watch for. While the companies have tried to crack down on hate speech, they acknowledge they have been slow to act. Some content that violates Facebook rules thrives in private groups. â¢ Can you identify posts designed to fool you? Take our quiz. âFear,â by the veteran journalist Bob Woodward, is the latest book to describe top officials working to undermine President Trumpâs impulses and privately insulting him. The anecdotes, gathered by nameless interviews with current and former officials, include Defense Secretary Jim Mattis comparing Mr. Trump to a âfifth or sixth grader,â and Gary Cohn, then the chief economic adviser, removing an important letter from the Oval Office desk so the president would forget to sign it. (According to the book, he did forget.) Mr. Trump accused Mr. Woodward of making up quotes and of running âa con on the public.â â¢ Here are the bookâs key takeaways and our review. Hiring the former N.F.L. quarterback who led player protests for an ad campaign is in line with decades of practice by a company that rarely shies away from politics. Some people burned their shoes in protest, while others cheered. But analysts say the risk could pay off with young customers, many of whom want their brands to take social positions. â¢ Mr. Kaepernick has controlled his own narrative largely by remaining silent. He has refused interviews and uses his Twitter account mostly to share othersâ thoughts. â¢ Amazon hit $1 trillion in value on Tuesday, becoming the second U.S. company, after Apple, to cross the once unthinkable threshold. â¢ Richard Liu, the founder of the Chinese online retailer JD.com, was arrested in Minnesota on Friday on a rape allegation, the police said on Tuesday. â¢ Wealthy countries have effectively outsourced their carbon pollution by importing more steel, cement and other goods. â¢ Britain needs stronger unions, an increased minimum wage, more affordable housing and higher taxes on the rich to to address its economic failings and rising inequality, according to a report by a committee that included academics, business executives, a trade union leader and the archbishop of Canterbury. â¢ U.S. stocks were down on Tuesday. Hereâs a snapshot of global markets today. Tips for a more fulfilling life. â¢ Scared to be a parent? Books and consultants can help. â¢ How to be a millionaire before youâre 30, then retire. â¢ Recipe of the day: Miso provides caramelization in this baked cod in buttery bread crumbs. â¢ Battle over health care  A new challenge to Obamacare will begin in Texas today. Hereâs whatâs at stake, and what to expect in oral arguments. â¢ Robert Mueller eases his demands The special counsel is said to be willing to accept written answers from President Trump on some questions in the Russia investigation. â¢ Deadly storm rips into Japan The country has been hit by its strongest typhoon in 25 years, leaving at least 11 people dead, 600 injured and thousands trapped at a major airport. â¢ From internet obscurity to a packed stadium Sheck Wes recorded âMo Bamba,â a rap anthem that was uploaded to SoundCloud with little fanfare, in about 20 minutes and one take. Those involved told our reporter how the hit came together. â¢ At the U.S. Open Serena Williams made the semifinals, and Rafael Nadal outlasted Dominic Thiem in a late-night classic. Follow  our tennis coverage here. â¢ Steak that doesnât break the bank  Talking to your butcher can help you find a flavorful cut and make you a better cook. Hereâs more from this weekâs Food section. â¢ Best of late-night TV Seth Meyers objected to the idea that President Trump is appointing a Supreme Court justice while under investigation: âThatâs like Bonnie getting arrested and saying, âYou know whoâd make a great judge? Clyde!ââ â¢ Quotation of the day âThis is not the cops who grab you on the street and push your face onto the ground. This is someone with intelligent greetings, compliments and gallantry. But the essence is the same.â â Nataliya Gryaznevich, an employee of a pro-democracy group in Russia who was approached by someone hoping to make her a government informer. â¢ The Times, in other words Hereâs an image of todayâs front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles. â¢ What weâre reading Kevin Roose, our tech columnist, recommends this BuzzFeed News article: âIâm so curious about how smart, idealistic workers at Facebook resolve the cognitive dissonance of being told theyâre changing the world for good and then reading things like this piece, about how the Philippine president, Rodrigo Duterte, used Facebook to fuel his bloody war on drugs.â One hundred years ago, the world was in the throes of World War I. The war weighed heavily on America, even on one of its favorite pastimes: baseball. A âwork or fightâ order for men in nonessential jobs was issued in July 1918, and the baseball season was cut short. On this day that year, the World Series began in Chicago. It was the earliest calendar date in the history of the series. And the game, between the Boston Red Sox and Chicago Cubs, provided another first. As the small crowd stood for the seventh-inning stretch, the military band began to play âThe Star-Spangled Banner.â Red Sox third baseman Fred Thomas, playing while on furlough from the Navy, stood at attention with a military salute. âFirst the song was taken up by a few, then others joined, and when the final notes came, a great volume of melody rolled across the field,â said a spirited Times report. The song was âan outburst of patriotism which caused every motherâs son in the stands to forget all about baseball.â It was the first time the anthem was sung at a major American sporting event. The song was played for the rest of the series, and for many more games to come. Remy Tumin wrote todayâs Back Story. _____ Your Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Check out our full range of free newsletters here. What would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com. Follow Daniel Victor on Twitter: @bydanielvictor. Advertisement

author: CARL HULSE
content: “Reviewing Judge Kavanaugh’s staff secretary documents would teach us nothing about his legal views,” Mr. Grassley said. The hearing is presenting a formidable challenge to Mr. Grassley, who over his long career has sought to cultivate a reputation for fairne… [+1303 chars]
description: Thirty years of warfare over judicial nominations culminated on Tuesday in the chaotic beginning of Senate consideration of the nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.
title: On Washington: A New Reality for Court Confirmations: Pandemonium, Protesters and Partisanship
text: Advertisement Supported by On Washington By Carl Hulse WASHINGTON â Welcome to the new reality of Supreme Court confirmation hearings â pandemonium, protesters and razor-sharp partisan lines. Thirty years of warfare over judicial nominations culminated on Tuesday in the chaotic beginning of Senate consideration of the nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, a tumultuous 90-minute first act that no one in the hearing room had ever seen before in decades of such events. Democrats on the typically staid, decorous committee immediately interrupted Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who leads the panel, as he opened the proceedings. They sought to postpone the hearing, fuming over a Labor Day night dump of 42,000 pages of documents less than 24 hours before the committee would convene. Protesters, mostly women, shouted objections to Judge Kavanaugh and President Trump from the public seats throughout the day and were ejected by the Capitol Police. Republicans, many of them well acquainted with Judge Kavanaugh for years, seethed. Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Republican, lamented that the committee was being subjected to âmob ruleâ and that if the hearing room was a courtroom, the Democrats would be held in contempt. The nominee â and his family and friends â sat stoically absorbing the scene that must have been somewhat overwhelming. But it should not have been unexpected. Democrats, with little recourse for stopping the nomination under changes in Senate confirmation practices, were determined to make a loud show of resistance and deploy any available weapons, which at this stage amounted to lodging procedural objections, issuing vehement complaints and articulating fears about the decline of the Senateâs role in confirmations. âIâm just sorry to see the Senate Judiciary Committee descend this way,â said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and a former chairman of the panel. âIâve felt privileged to serve here under both Republican and Democratic leadership for over 40 years. This is not the Senate Judiciary Committee I saw when I came to the U.S. Senate.â The intense clash came just days after a series of memorial services for Senator John McCain and a call to bipartisanship, but that sentiment was definitely not in attendance at the hearing. Republicans wryly noted that Democrats admitted they had conferred with Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, over the weekend about their hearing strategy. Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, said opponents were spouting âdrivelâ and âderanged commentsâ about Judge Kavanaugh. Republicans circulated their scorecard listing the number of Democratic interruptions (63) versus mentions of Judge Kavanaughâs judicial opinions (âjust 12â). Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, attributed the commotion to âfolks who want to run for president, who want their moment in the spotlight.â âFrankly, I wish we could drop all this nonsense,â Mr. Hatch said. But Democrats were in no mood to drop their furious objections. Their central complaint is that Republicans have moved forward with the confirmation despite the fact that tens of thousands of documents from Judge Kavanaughâs time in the White House have not been disclosed and that the National Archives was not given time to do its own traditional records review. Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois and longtime member of the panel, told Judge Kavanaugh that the lack of records amounts to a â35-month black hole in your White House career.â To Democrats, the Kavanaugh timetable stands in stark â and infuriating â contrast to the Republican decision in 2016 to deny any hearing at all to Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Barack Obamaâs nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court after his death. âWhen Justice Scalia died, Republicans refused to even meet â even a meeting in their office â with President Obamaâs nominee and held the seat open for one year,â said Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the senior Democrat on the panel. âNow with a Republican in the White House, theyâve changed their position. The majority rushed into this hearing and is refusing to even look at the nomineeâs full record.â Republicans responded that the real way to judge the nomineeâs record was through his more than 300 opinions while on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, calling much of the material sought by Democrats irrelevant. âReviewing Judge Kavanaughâs staff secretary documents would teach us nothing about his legal views,â Mr. Grassley said. The hearing is presenting a formidable challenge to Mr. Grassley, who over his long career has sought to cultivate a reputation for fairness. Democrats appealed to that desire to be seen as equitable, even as they carefully criticized the way he is presiding over the Kavanaugh review. âSir, based upon your own principles, your own values, I call for at least to have a debate or a vote on these issues and not for us to rush through this process,â said Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, who has worked closely with Mr. Grassley on criminal justice issues. At the same time, Mr. Grassley was pressed by his own Republican Party for giving Democrats too much latitude in making their case. But Mr. Grassley said he was willing to take as long as it might to move forward. âWeâre going to be in session Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday until we get done this week,â Mr. Grassley said. âSo however long people want to take, weâre going to not necessarily accommodate all obstruction, but if people got something to say, this chairmanâs going to let them say it.â Democrats say their concerns about the nomination, the hearing and the way it was being conducted were only heightened by Mr. Trumpâs weekend tweet expressing unhappiness with the recent indictment of two House Republicans. They seem certain to press Judge Kavanaugh about the presidentâs view and his own on whether the president is above the law. âAs a former prosecutor, this is abhorrent to me,â Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, said about the presidentâs tweet. Democrats know they have little chance of slowing, let alone stopping, the confirmation of Judge Kavanaugh as Republicans seem solidly behind him. Senator Mazie K. Hirono, Democrat of Hawaii, admitted as much, saying that some battles are worth fighting despite the likely outcome. And Democrats appear quite ready to fight to the extent they can. Get politics and Washington news updates via Facebook, Twitter and the Morning Briefing newsletter.    video Advertisement

description: Judge Brett Kavanaugh at his confirmation hearing in the Senate two weeks ago.
title: Kavanaugh and the Politics of Bad Faith
text: Advertisement Supported by Why the modern G.O.P. keeps abandoning principles it claims to honor. By Paul Krugman Opinion Columnist Activists in Maine opposed to the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court are trying to put pressure on Susan Collins, the stateâs Republican senator. If Collins votes for Kavanaugh, they say, they will donate substantial sums to her opponent in the next election. Whatever you think of Kavanaugh, this is surely a legitimate tactic: Donors and activists try to influence politiciansâ votes all the time, often by warning of adverse electoral consequences if the politicians make what the activists consider the wrong choice. Last year, for example, major Republican donors openly threatened to withhold contributions unless the party gave them a big tax cut. But now Collins, other Republicans and conservative activists are describing the pressure over Kavanaugh as âbribery,â âextortionâ and âblackmail.â And some of those claiming that normal political activism is somehow illegitimate are the very same big donors who warned Republicans to pass tax cuts or else. Calling this about-face hypocrisy is fair, but feels inadequate. Weâre looking at something much bigger and more pervasive than mere hypocrisy: Weâre talking about bad faith on an epic scale. âBad faithâ is, by the way, a legal term, referring to âentering into an agreement without the intention or means to fulfill it, or violating basic standards of honesty.â In politics, it usually means pretending to be committed to principles you abandon the moment they become inconvenient. And bad faith in this sense pervades almost everything the modern G.O.P. says and does. The very process that brought Kavanaugh to the brink of a lifetime Supreme Court appointment was saturated in bad faith. Remember, Republicans wouldnât even give President Barack Obamaâs nominee a hearing, claiming that because Obama was late in his second term the process should wait, leaving a court seat vacant for more than a year, to let voters weigh in. Now theyâre trying to ram Kavanaugh through in a matter of weeks, despite incomplete vetting of his legal record and major questions about his personal history. (Explosive sexual charges aside, will anyone ask about his huge personal debts?) Why the rush? Because thereâs a chance the G.O.P. will lose the Senate soon. That whole thing about letting the voters have their say was dishonest from the beginning. And there are many more examples. Remember when Paul Ryan posed as the ultimate guardian of fiscal responsibility, releasing manifestoes warning in dire terms of the âcrushing burden of debtâ? The moment Republicans found themselves in control of the White House, Ryan helped ram through a huge tax cut that will add $1.5 trillion to the deficit. Ryanâs hyperventilating about the deficit was focused mainly on social programs; in particular, he proposed large cuts to Medicare, converting it into a voucher program that would eventually receive far less money than the existing program. Some pundits praised his courage in making such a proposal. But now a political action committee tied to Ryan is running ads falsely accusing Democrats of â¦ planning to cut Medicare. Wait, thereâs more. For years, Republicans tarred their opponents as unpatriotic. Remember the whole thing about Obama supposedly apologizing for America? Now we have a president who praises brutal foreign dictators and whose national security adviser and campaign chairman were both undisclosed foreign agents â and it doesnât seem to bother the G.O.P. at all. Oh, and letâs not forget that Bill Clinton was impeached over a consensual affair, because Republicans insisted that the presidentâs personal behavior must be above reproach. Need I say more? And there are many, many more such stories. In fact, whatâs really hard is to come up with significant areas of politics or policy where Republicans are acting in good faith, where their deeds really correspond to the principles they claim to have. Offhand, I canât come up with any examples. Why has the G.O.P. become the party of bad faith? Mainly, I suspect, because its core policy agenda of cutting taxes on the rich while slashing social programs is deeply unpopular. So to win elections it must obscure its true policies â like the Republicans now claiming, falsely, that they want to protect Americans with pre-existing medical conditions â and constantly pretend to stand for things it doesnât actually care about, from fiscal probity to personal responsibility. The key thing to realize about the G.O.P.âs near-total commitment to bad faith is that voters arenât the only victims. Itâs true that many Trump supporters will get a rude shock if Republicans hold Congress, imagining that theyâre making America great and losing their health care coverage instead. But bad faith takes a moral toll on Republican politicians, too. We keep seeing people who once appeared to have some sense of decency turn into abject apparatchiks. Remember when Lindsey Graham seemed to have some independent conscience? Is Susan Collins next? Instead of attacking those activists back in Maine, she should be thanking them, for giving her one last chance to save her political soul. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion), join the Facebook political discussion group, Voting While Female, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.  Paul Krugman has been an Opinion columnist since 2000 and is also a Distinguished Professor at the City University of New York Graduate Center. He won the 2008 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his work on international trade and economic geography.  @PaulKrugman  Advertisement

description: On his first full day of questioning, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trump’s nominee to the Supreme Court, would not say whether a president could be subpoenaed or pardon himself.
title: Kavanaugh Ducks Questions on Presidential Powers and Subpoenas
text: Advertisement Supported by By Michael D. Shear, Adam Liptak and Sheryl Gay Stolberg WASHINGTON â Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trumpâs nominee to the Supreme Court, on Wednesday dodged direct questions about whether the Constitution would allow Mr. Trump to use the powers of the presidency to thwart the Russia collusion and obstruction investigations that are swirling around his administration. Testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee on a grueling second day of hearings, Judge Kavanaugh refused to say whether he believes Mr. Trump, as a sitting president, could be subpoenaed by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, to testify in the sprawling inquiry. Answering questions in public for the first time since his nomination, the judge also declined to say whether Mr. Trump could escape legal jeopardy by pardoning himself or his associates. âIâm not going to answer hypothetical questions of that sort,â Judge Kavanaugh said, insisting that it would be inappropriate for a Supreme Court nominee to publicly offer views on issues that might come before the court once he is a justice. Judge Kavanaugh also declined to say he would disqualify himself from cases concerning Mr. Trump. In a hearing that began in the morning, stretched into the night, and seesawed between intense grilling by Democrats and fawning praise by Republicans, Judge Kavanaugh sought to present himself as an evenhanded arbiter of the law rather than a partisan ideologue driven by a desire to carry out a Republican policy agenda. He parried questions, without any obvious blunders, on matters ranging from abortion to gun rights to executive powers and arcane provisions of antitrust law. At least two more days of hearings remain, but absent a startling revelation, he appears headed to confirmation by the end of the month because Republicans remain largely united behind his nomination. But Judge Kavanaugh did little to win over Democrats. Speaking generally, he insisted that he would be an independent justice prepared to rule against the president who appointed him. âNo one is above the law in our constitutional system,â he said. At the same time, he did not retreat from views offered in law review articles that revealed a robust conception of presidential power, views he said had been forged in large part by five years of service in the White House under President George W. Bush. Under attack from progressives and Democrats who say he will roll back abortion rights, Judge Kavanaugh said he believes that Roe v. Wade, the 1973 landmark Supreme Court case establishing a womanâs right to an abortion, was âsettled as a precedent of the Supreme Court,â and as such, deserves respect from judges. But he did not say whether he believes Roe was correctly decided. But then he noted a subsequent case, the 1992 case of Planned Parenthood v. Casey, which narrowed the scope of Roe at the same time that it reaffirmed Roe as a precedent. Casey, which gave states the authority to regulate abortion so long as those regulations do not pose an âundue burdenâ on the woman, is âprecedent on precedent,â he said. On that issue and others, Judge Kavanaugh repeatedly sought to demonstrate empathy, telling senators that when it comes to understanding the real-life implications of abortion, âI donât live in a bubble. I understand. I live in the real world.â He defended his dissent last year in Garza v. Hargan, in which he argued that the Trump administration should have been allowed to temporarily block an undocumented teenager from having an abortion while it sought to place her with a sponsor. He said he had followed Supreme Court precedents, even as he acknowledged that there was no directly applicable case. âI did my level best in an emergency posture,â Judge Kavanaugh said. He said that took the teenagerâs situation into account. âI tried to recognize the real-world effects on her,â he said. âI said consider the circumstances. Sheâs a 17-year-old, by herself, in a foreign country. In a facility where sheâs detained. And she has no one to talk to. And sheâs pregnant. Now that is a difficult situation.â Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, said Judge Kavanaugh had participated in an attempt to deny the teenager access to a constitutional right, placing her health at risk. [Have questions about the hearings? Submit them for our Supreme Court correspondent.] Protesters continued to interrupt the hearing, adding to the tension after an opening day on Tuesday in which dozens of people were arrested after loudly disrupting the proceedings. There were more arrests on Wednesday. One woman was led out of the hearing room shouting âsham president, sham justiceâ; another hollered, âYouâre gaslighting the American people,â drowning out Judge Kavanaugh as he calmly carried on. Democratic senators angrily railed against a swiftly moving confirmation process, accusing Republicans on the committee of refusing to make public documents that they said call into question Judge Kavanaughâs honesty about his past congressional testimony and his record as a political operative and a lawyer in the Bush White House. Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, raised two Bush-era scandals with Judge Kavanaugh, and he suggested that Bush White House emails in the Judiciary Committeeâs possession may contradict testimony the nominee made more than a decade ago â if only they could be released publicly. One of the scandals was the disclosure in late 2003 and 2004 that a Republican Judiciary Committee staff member had infiltrated the Democratsâ confidential internal files about which of President George W. Bushâs judicial nominees to try to block and with what tactics. The other was the disclosure that after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, the Bush administration had secretly ordered the National Security Agency to intercept Americansâ phone calls and emails without obtaining the judicial warrants seemingly required by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. At his appeals court confirmation hearing in 2006, Judge Kavanaugh â who had worked as an associate White House counsel in the Bush administration â told senators that he did not know anything about the infiltration of Senate Democratsâ files on judicial nomination fights or about the warrantless wiretapping program before they eventually became public. But Mr. Leahy indicated that documents marked âcommittee confidentialâ â and kept secret from the public â provide evidence that Judge Kavanaugh had contact with Manuel Miranda, then a Republican staff member on the Judiciary Committee, and had more involvement with the surveillance program than he had acknowledged. âI am concerned because there is evidence that Mr. Miranda provided you with materials that were stolen from me,â Mr. Leahy said. âAnd that would contradict your prior testimony. It is also clear from public emails â and Iâm refraining from going into nonpublic ones â that you had reason to believe materials were obtained inappropriately at the time.â Judge Kavanaugh insisted that everything he had testified to before was â100 percent accurate,â but indicated that he was not sure what Mr. Leahy was referring to. With Democrats casting him as a partisan who was nominated by Mr. Trump only to protect the president, Judge Kavanaugh spent considerable time trying to demonstrate his independence. One case he cited to buttress his argument was notable: United States v. Nixon, the 1974 decision in which the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that President Richard M. Nixon had to comply with a subpoena seeking tapes of his conversations in the Oval Office. In 1999, Judge Kavanaugh mused aloud that âmaybe Nixon was wrongly decided.â He made the statement soon after serving under Ken Starr, the independent counsel who investigated President Bill Clinton. Judge Kavanaughâs allies have said he meant the statement as a critique of the legal strategy of Mr. Clintonâs lawyers. But on Wednesday, he called it âone of the greatest moments because of the political pressures of the time.â âThe courts stood up for judicial independence in a moment of national crisis,â Judge Kavanaugh said, ranking the decision as one of the Supreme Courtâs greatest achievements. Judge Kavanaugh also sought to portray himself as an advocate for women. He described sexual harassment allegations against Alex Kozinski, a former federal appellate judge for whom he once clerked, as âa gut punch for me,â and said he knew nothing of the behavior. And he told the committee he has made aggressive effort to hire female clerks; 25 of his 48 clerks were women. Judge Kavanaugh sidestepped questions from Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, about his personal views on affirmative action and racial profiling, even as Mr. Booker said Judge Kavanaugh was hostile to affirmation action and open to racial profiling. But the judge defended his decision upholding South Carolinaâs voter identification law, arguing that he had taken the âreal-world effectâ into account and had forced the state to take steps to insure that the law did not impose an undue burden on black people. On gun rights, Judge Kavanaugh told the committee the Second Amendment protected the right of Americans to own semiautomatic rifles because they are in âcommon useâ and not a âdangerous and unusual weaponâ â a position he took in a much-publicized 2011 dissent, which he said was rooted in Supreme Court precedent. That prompted an outcry from Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the top Democrat on the judiciary panel. âHow do you reconcile what youâve just said with the hundreds of school shootings using assault weapons that have taken place in recent history?â she asked. âSenator, of course the violence in the schools is something we all detest,â the judge replied. But he added, âAs a judge my job, as I saw it, was to follow the Second Amendment opinion of the Supreme Court.â Get politics and Washington news updates via Facebook, Twitter and the Morning Briefing newsletter.
