content: Noteworthy • Maybe skip the aspirin, study says Millions take aspirin to prevent heart attacks, strokes and cancer. New research shows older people in good health may not need it. • Emmys are to be awarded tonight The night honoring TV’s best begins at 8 p.m.… [+1286 chars]
description: A playground in Lumberton, N.C., on Sunday. Now a tropical depression, Florence has left widespread and potentially catastrophic flooding across the Carolinas.
title: Florence, Brett Kavanaugh, Soon-Yi Previn: Your Monday News Briefing
text: Advertisement Supported by By Chris Stanford  (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) Good morning. Hereâs what you need to know: â¢ Officials in the Philippines said today that emergency workers had recovered 43 bodies after a landslide, potentially doubling the countryâs death toll from Typhoon Mangkhut. Here are the latest updates from the storm, which continued a path of destruction through Hong Kong and southern China, where at least four people died. Using data from a NASA satellite, we looked at the typhoonâs intense rainfall in 3-D. In the U.S., the governor of North Carolina warned on Sunday that Florence, which is now a tropical depression, has ânever been more dangerous than it is right now.â At least 17 people have been killed in North and South Carolina, and a flash-flood watch is in effect for most of the area today. Read the latest here. How to help: Here are some of the organizations working to aid those affected by Typhoon Mangkhut and  Hurricane Florence. â¢ In an interview on Sunday, Christine Blasey Ford accused the Supreme Court nominee of sexually assaulting her when they were teenagers in the early 1980s. Ms. Ford, a research psychologist at Palo Alto University in California, said that a drunken Mr. Kavanaugh had pinned her on a bed during a party, groped her and covered her mouth to keep her from screaming. â¢ Whatâs next: Judge Kavanaugh has denied the accusations, and a Senate committee is scheduled to vote on the nomination on Thursday. The White House aide Kellyanne Conway said today that Ms. Ford âwill be heard.â â¢ A larger share of the U.S. population is foreign-born now than at any time since 1910. In recent years, the trend is not so much with Latin Americans crossing the border, but with educated people from Asia obtaining visas. Many of those immigrants came through family reunification policies that the Trump administration hopes to scale back. Some experts predict that the number of immigrants granted permanent legal residency in this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, will show a rare decline. â¢ Looking to 2020: Michael Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, is considering running for president as a Democrat. But he has sharp disagreements with the party on issues including bank regulation and stop-and-frisk police tactics. â¢ New York Cityâs efforts to pull its transit system from crisis have been hampered by ancient signaling systems, creaky trains and, increasingly, by people venturing onto the tracks. There were nearly 900 incidents last year in which someone was on the tracks or hit by a train after getting too close while on the platform. This year, that number is set to rise. â¢ The cause: Subway officials arenât sure, but thereâs speculation it may be in part because of the many homeless people inside the system or the number of smartphones that fall onto the tracks. â¢ Time magazine will be sold to Marc Benioff, the co-founder of the software company Salesforce, and his wife, Lynne, for $190 million. â¢ Walmart has faced political resistance for years to opening a store in New York City. It now has a foothold there through its e-commerce site, Jet.com. â¢ In a breakthrough for green energy, two hydrogen-powered trains are expected to go into service today in Germany. Itâs one of the headlines to watch this week. â¢ U.S. stocks were mixed on Friday. Hereâs a snapshot of global markets today. Tips for a more fulfilling life. â¢ Worried about falling ill or being quarantined on a flight? Donât be â it happens very rarely, and even then itâs usually minor. â¢ Cook and eat well in your first apartment or dorm room. â¢ Recipe of the day: For a meatless meal, try crisp, baked tofu with a lemon-tahini sauce. â¢ The governor of Massachusetts said it was safe for thousands of residents to return home, after gas leaks touched off a series of explosions that killed one person and injured more than 20. â¢ A Border Patrol agent was arrested in connection with the deaths of four women in recent weeks around the city of Laredo, Tex. â¢ In her first extended comments on the fraught history between the director Woody Allen and the Farrow family, Soon-Yi Previn described her mother, Mia Farrow, as a demeaning and sometimes violent figure. Mr. Allen, who married Ms. Previn in 1997, worked with and dated Ms. Farrow for years. â¢ Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya set a world record for a marathon. His time of 2 hours 1 minute 39 seconds broke the previous record by more than a minute. â¢ In the N.F.L., Patrick Mahomes threw for six touchdowns to lead the Kansas City Chiefs over the Pittsburgh Steelers. Here are the scores and highlights from Week 2. â¢ âPredator,â the latest installment in the alien horror franchise, earned $24 million and the top spot at the North American box office. â¢ Maybe skip the aspirin, study says Millions take aspirin to prevent heart attacks, strokes and cancer. New research shows older people in good health may not need it. â¢ Emmys are to be awarded tonight The night honoring TVâs best begins at 8 p.m. Eastern and will most likely be a battle between two former winners: âGame of Thronesâ and âThe Handmaidâs Tale.â Hereâs a list of the nominees. â¢ The end of âMy Struggleâ The sixth and final volume of Karl Ove Knausgaardâs novel will be published on Tuesday. In an excerpt in the Times Magazine, the author confronts the central mystery of autobiographical fiction. â¢ Quotation of the day âItâs easy to say, âI love God,â but put on your boots, get your hands dirty.â â Jim Pennington, senior pastor of Temple Church in New Bern, N.C., who helped pull about 30 people from floodwaters. â¢ The Times, in other words Hereâs an image of todayâs front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles. â¢ What weâre reading Alisha Haridasani Gupta, one of our Morning Briefing writers, recommends this piece from The Pudding: âI, like many women, yearn for a simple pleasure: pockets. This piece takes a sharp, detailed look at how ridiculously small (and therefore useless) pockets in womenâs clothing are. It even has a fun graphic of all the things that can fit into jeans pockets.â Last week, two Russians named by Britain as the prime suspects in a nerve agent attack said that they  had merely been visiting the âwonderfulâ English city of Salisbury as tourists. They wouldnât have been alone. Near the famous Stonehenge site, the city is about 90 miles southwest of London and is perhaps most famous for its Gothic cathedral, which attracts half a million visitors a year. In âNotes From a Small Island,â the best-selling author Bill Bryson wrote, âThere is no doubt in my mind that Salisbury Cathedral is the single most beautiful structure in England.â The main body of the cathedral was completed in 1258 and, as noted by one of the suspects in an interview on Russian TV, âItâs famous for its 123-meter spire.â (Thatâs equivalent to 404 feet, making it the tallest church spire in Britain.) The cathedral contains the best preserved of the four original copies of Magna Carta, the 13th-century document restricting the powers of the monarch. Itâs also the burial place of the former British prime minister Edward Heath, and is home to what is thought to be the worldâs oldest mechanical clock. The cathedral has also featured widely in literature and art, particularly in the work of the landscape painter John Constable. Chris Stanford wrote todayâs Back Story. _____ Your Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. To receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, sign up here. Check out our full range of free newsletters here. What would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com. Follow Chris Stanford on Twitter: @stanfordc. Advertisement

author: MICHAEL TOMASKY
content: Except maybe not. At that point, Republicans, far from accepting defeat, will surely start aiming fire at the three Democrats. Their opponents will taunt them about Judge Kavanaugh on the campaign trail. Right-wing money will pour in to their states for pro-K… [+1909 chars]
description: Senator Joe Manchin, a West Virginia Democrat, listening to Judge Brett Kavanaugh testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Sept. 6.
title: What the Kavanaugh Accusations Mean for Red-State Democrats
text: Advertisement Supported by Things just got a lot more complicated for Joe Manchin. By Michael Tomasky Michael Tomasky is a columnist for The Daily Beast and a contributing opinion writer. A view seems to have taken hold in Washington that the sexual assault allegations against Brett Kavanaugh by Christine Blasey Ford have let red-state Senate Democrats off the hook. These Democrats â chiefly Joe Donnelly of Indiana, Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota and Joe Manchin of West Virginia, the three Democrats who voted to confirm Neil Gorsuch in April 2017 â all face re-election in just seven weeks in states where President Trump is popular, and where majorities presumably would support Judge Kavanaughâs elevation to the Supreme Court. But now, some say, the allegations against the nominee provide reason enough for them to vote no. Jim Manley, a former longtime Democratic Senate aide who knows these matters well, told Reuters on Tuesday: âFor those Democrats up for re-election from states that Trump carried, they now have absolutely no reason to vote for Kavanaugh. Period. End of story. They have all the cover they need.â Several talking heads on cable news said much the same thing Tuesday. Iâm not sure itâs that simple. Assuming Judge Kavanaughâs nomination is not withdrawn and the Republicans continue to fight for him, these three Democrats and possibly one or two others will still find themselves in a tough position. In fact, if a couple of Republicans defect from Judge Kavanaugh, these Democrats will be in an even tougher spot than before.  Imagine this hypothetical. Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski, the two Republican senators who are under the most pressure to oppose confirmation, decide to do so. That takes Judge Kavanaugh down to 49 votes. Game over. Except maybe not. At that point, Republicans, far from accepting defeat, will surely start aiming fire at the three Democrats. Their opponents will taunt them about Judge Kavanaugh on the campaign trail. Right-wing money will pour in to their states for pro-Kavanaugh (and pro-Trump) TV ads. Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader in the Senate, will let this play out and may schedule the vote for as late as he can â mid-October, even late October â to make the Democrats sweat. That will constitute enormous pressure on the red-state Democrats. If they sense their opponents are gaining steam, they may well think: Why should I cast a vote thatâs going to cost me my seat? Especially when even if we defeat Judge Kavanaugh, weâre just going to get someone else whoâs every bit as conservative? If one of them moves to a pro-Kavanaugh position, itâs likely that all three will move. Hereâs why. There is a standing agreement among minority parties in the Senate that in such situations, no one wants to be the 50th vote. The lone senator who provides the 50th vote can be blamed and reviled. But if all three move together, then one of them canât be singled out as having cast the dreaded 50th vote. This is one big reason there are so few 50-to-50 votes in the Senate. In fact, when one side sees it has lost, a couple other senators who can afford to cast the vote will often join in to give their colleagues cover. Beginning to see how this works? Now imagine a second scenario. Imagine that Ms. Collins and Ms. Murkowski vote no, but this time they are joined by two other Republicans, Jeff Flake of Arizona and Bob Corker of Tennessee. Now, Judge Kavanaugh is down to 47 votes. And more important, the air will be out of his balloon, emotionally. At that point, I think the three Democrats will be fully off the hook. And, of course, thereâs a third scenario (at least!), which I discussed here earlier, and itâs probably still the most likely one. All 51 Republicans stand pat, in which case some Democrats will go ahead and confirm Judge Kavanaugh. But their votes wonât matter. Whether you got 51 votes or 55 or 100, they still call you Mr. Associate Justice. If all this is maddening to you, I canât say I blame you. Why donât they just do the right thing? Well, sure. But here it gets more complicated still. Whatâs the right thing? The Democrats, say the experts, now have a chance of recapturing control of the Senate. Their candidates are looking good in Nevada and Arizona and are competitive in Tennessee and even Texas. That majority would hinge on winning three of those four seats. But it would also depend on red-state senators like Mr. Donnelly, Ms. Heitkamp and Mr. Manchin holding theirs. Voting against Judge Kavanaugh might jeopardize that. In the long run, whatâs better: the Democrats helping to confirm Judge Kavanaugh and winning a majority, or standing firm against him but remaining the minority? Many would say it doesnât have to come down to those two choices, and theyâre right. All this is unknowable. In the Democratsâ dream world, they defeat Judge Kavanaugh, win the majority, block the Republicans from getting a nominee through in the lame-duck session and then keep the seat open for two years. That could happen, too! All will hinge on a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on the sexual assault allegations, scheduled for Monday. If Ms. Blasey looks convincing, if Judge Kavanaugh looks evasive. â¦ But donât think the mere accusations doom the nominee with all Democrats. This news isnât playing in Bismarck and Charleston the way itâs playing in Washington and New York. Red-state senators probably need still a little more cover. Michael Tomasky is a columnist for The Daily Beast, editor of Democracy: A Journal of Ideas and a contributing opinion writer. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion). Michael Tomasky is a columnist for The Daily Beast, editor of Democracy: A Journal of Ideas and a contributing opinion writer.   Advertisement

author: LINDA GREENHOUSE
content: The other case, Al-Adahi v. Obama, overturned a district judge’s grant of habeas corpus to Mohammed Al-Adahi, a Yemeni who had once attended an Al Qaeda training camp and stayed at an Al Qaeda guesthouse. “In all, there can be no doubt that Al-Adahi was more … [+3591 chars]
description: As an appeals court judge, he signed on to decisions that deprived detainees of the chance to contest their detentions.
title: What Guantánamo Says About Kavanaugh
text:
Advertisement Supported by As an appeals court judge, he signed on to decisions that deprived detainees of the chance to contest their detentions. By Linda Greenhouse Contributing Opinion Writer  For a long time, I made it a point to write about GuantÃ¡namo at least once a year. There was usually some new development to hang a column on. But the real reason was that, having chronicled the riveting legal saga sparked by the George W. Bush administrationâs decision to create a legal black hole at the U.S. Navy base there in which to imprison hundreds of men captured in Pakistan and Afghanistan in the aftermath of 9/11, I felt an obligation to show that I was still watching, even if most people no longer were. But gradually, as President Barack Obama left office with his promise to close GuantÃ¡namo unfulfilled, and as President Trump blustered about opening the island prison to new arrivals, and as the military commission that is supposed to try the accused 9/11 perpetrators has yet to set a trial date after six years, there has seemed nothing to say. (Since his inauguration, President Trump has permitted the release of one GuantÃ¡namo detainee, leaving an inmate count of 40, down from 780 at its peak.) True, back in June, when Supreme Court Justice Anthony M. Kennedy announced his retirement, there were a few comments about his important role in the Supreme Court majority that pushed back against both the White House and Congress in a series of GuantÃ¡namo decisions more than a decade ago. But those few references were quickly buried in the avalanche of speculation on what Justice Kennedyâs departure will mean for the future of gay rights and the right to abortion. Iâm writing about GuantÃ¡namo now because of a little noticed order that came down earlier this month from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Thatâs the court on which President Trumpâs Supreme Court nominee, Brett Kavanaugh, has sat for the past 12 years. The order, and the appeal that produced it, provide a bridge between past and present, between Justice Kennedy and his former law clerk who would replace him, between a battle over the rule of law now fading into history and a battle over the future of the Supreme Court that will play out when Judge Kavanaughâs Senate confirmation hearing begins next week.  The three-sentence order did not directly concern Judge Kavanaugh. He and his newest colleague on the appeals court, Gregory Katsas, âdid not participate in this matter,â a footnote informs us. The courtâs other nine judges did, and all agreed not to grant an unusual request to hear, as a full court (en banc in legal terminology), an appeal brought on behalf of a GuantÃ¡namo detainee named Khalid Ahmed Qassim. Such a request typically comes after a three-judge panel has heard an appeal, but Mr. Qassimâs lawyers sought to skip that step, deeming it futile.  Mr. Qassim, a 41-year-old Yemeni, is one of GuantÃ¡namo âforever prisoners,â having been held without charge for 16 years. He filed a habeas corpus petition in Federal District Court in Washington, D.C. in July 2004, shortly after the Supreme Court ruled in Rasul v. Bush that, contrary to the governmentâs argument, federal judges had jurisdiction to hear such cases from GuantÃ¡namo inmates. Mr. Qassimâs petition, along with others, was kept in abeyance as cases that would inevitably bear on it traveled up and down the legal system. Finally, in May, a federal district judge, Thomas F. Hogan, denied the petition in a brief oral ruling. Binding precedent of the circuit left him no choice, the judge said. âJudge Hogan was correct that panel decisions of this court prevented him from granting relief to Mr. Qassim,â the detaineeâs lawyers told the appeals courtâs judges. And here is the link to Judge Kavanaugh. The lawyers cited four D.C. Circuit decisions that they say have flouted the Supreme Courtâs holding in Boumediene v. Bush, the 2008 decision that recognized a constitutional right â not simply a statutory right, as in the earlier Rasul case â for GuantÃ¡namo inmates to seek federal court review of the legality of their detention. The four decisions, the lawyers asserted, have left Mr. Qassim and others at GuantÃ¡namo âcaught in a trap from which they cannot escape based on rules set by panels of this court that are directly contrary to the Supreme Courtâs ruling in Boumediene.â Under federal court practice, panels within an appeals court must accept each othersâ decisions as binding, unless and until the full court announces a change of course. The Qassim case will now go to an ordinary three-judge panel, which may send it back to Judge Hogan for additional fact-finding in advance of a renewed appeal. Judge Kavanaugh did not write an opinion in any of the four cases. But he was a member of the panels that decided two of them, both in 2010, by 3-to-0 votes. One, Al-Bihani v. Obama, upheld the denial of habeas corpus for Ghaleb Al-Bihani, a Yemeni who claimed that before 9/11 he was merely a cook for a group in Afghanistan allied with the Talibanâs fight against the Northern Alliance. This support for the Taliban was sufficient to justify his continued detention, the panel held in an opinion by Judge Janice Rogers Brown. Wherever the outer bounds of material support lie, Judge Brown wrote, âthey clearly include traditional food operations essential to a fighting force and the carrying of arms.â (A government review board approved Mr. Al-Bihaniâs release in 2014, and he was transferred to Oman.) The other case, Al-Adahi v. Obama, overturned a district judgeâs grant of habeas corpus to Mohammed Al-Adahi, a Yemeni who had once attended an Al Qaeda training camp and stayed at an Al Qaeda guesthouse. âIn all, there can be no doubt that Al-Adahi was more likely than not part of Al Qaeda,â Judge A. Raymond Randolph wrote for the panel. In granting Mr. Al-Adahiâs petition, the district judge had found aspects of the governmentâs evidence unreliable. But judges must view the governmentâs evidence as a whole, not piece by piece, Judge Randolph wrote, in order to see whether taken as a whole it meets the deferential standard of âmore likely than not.â The government had easily met that test in Mr. Al-Adahiâs case, Judge Randolph said.  Mr. Al-Adahi was cleared for release in 2016 and transferred to the United Arab Emirates. Judge Randolph has been openly contemptuous of the Supreme Courtâs Boumediene decision. In a speech in 2011, he compared the justices to Daisy and Tom Buchanan in The Great Gatsby, characters who âsmashed things upâ and âlet other people clean up the mess they made.â Asked in an interview for Columbia Universityâs Rule of Law Oral History Project in 2013 whether it was âfair to say that you think the Supreme Court was all wet three times runningâ â a reference to the courtâs three rounds of GuantÃ¡namo rulings that culminated in Boumediene â Judge Randolph answered âYes.â In their appeal to the full D.C. Circuit in Mr. Qassimâs case, the lawyers noted that following the Boumediene decision in 2008, district judges heard 53 habeas corpus petitions from GuantÃ¡namo detainees and granted 38 of them, a rate of 70 percent. But since the four panel rulings that purported to interpret Boumediene, ânot a single habeas petition contested by the government has been granted, and every previous district court grant of habeas appealed by the government has been reversed.â As a result, they wrote, âthese ruling have eviscerated Boumedieneâs holding that GuantÃ¡namo detainees are entitled to a âmeaningful opportunityâ to contest the basis for their detentions.â The author of the majority opinion in Boumediene was Justice Kennedy. The vote was 5 to 4, and the split was even more bitter than the vote count suggests. Justice Antonin Scalia, in a dissenting opinion that Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel A. Alito Jr. also joined, warned of âdisastrous consequencesâ from the decision and predicted that âit will almost certainly cause Americans to die.â Justice Kennedyâs majority opinion was powerful, a paean to the rule of law that echoed well beyond a particular military prison on a particular island. âWithin the Constitutionâs separation-of-powers structure,â he wrote, âfew exercises of judicial power are as legitimate or as necessary as the responsibility to hear challenges to the authority of the Executive to imprison a person.â That was especially so when detention was by executive authority rather than following a trial and conviction for a crime, he said. âIn this context the need for habeas corpus is more urgent,â he added. âThe habeas court must have sufficient authority to conduct a meaningful review of both the cause for detention and the Executiveâs power to detain.â Did these words by his old boss ring in Judge Kavanaughâs ears as he signed on to opinions that left the promise of the Boumediene decision an empty one? And if not, why not? I donât know. But I do know that GuantÃ¡namo has always been a mirror that reflects back on ourselves. And the reflection in this instance gives us another hint of what the substitution of Brett Kavanaugh for Anthony Kennedy may mean for the future of the court and the country. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion), and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.  Linda Greenhouse, the winner of the 1998 Pulitzer Prize, writes on alternate Thursdays about the Supreme Court and the law. She reported on the Supreme Court for The Times from 1978 to 2008, and is the author of several books.
        Advertisement

author: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
content: In the interview, Ms. Ford said that the lasting trauma from the attack had “derailed me substantially for four or five years,” and had caused anxiety for years after that. Judge Kavanaugh, in his statement released last week, said: “I categorically and unequ… [+1283 chars]
description: “I thought he might inadvertently kill me,” said the woman, accusing Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh of sexual assault when the two were teenagers. He has denied the allegations.
title: Kavanaugh Accuser Comes Forward, Saying He Pinned Her on Bed and Groped Her
text: Advertisement Supported by By Sheryl Gay Stolberg WASHINGTON â President Trumpâs bid to confirm Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court was thrown into uncertainty on Sunday as a woman came forward with explosive allegations that Mr. Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers more than three decades ago. The woman, Christine Blasey Ford, 51, a research psychologist at Palo Alto University in Northern California, said in an interview with The Washington Post that during a high school party in the early 1980s, a drunken Mr. Kavanaugh pinned her on a bed, groped her and covered her mouth to keep her from screaming. âI thought he might inadvertently kill me,â the newspaper quoted her as saying. âHe was trying to attack me and remove my clothing.â Judge Kavanaugh has denied the accusations, and in a terse statement on Sunday, the White House said it stood by those denials. It signaled that it had no intention of pulling the nomination. But Ms. Fordâs decision to put her name behind accusations that began to circulate late last week â a choice made after weeks of reluctance â appeared to open a door to a delay in a Senate committee vote on the nomination scheduled for Thursday. The disclosure also injected a volatile #MeToo element into the confirmation debate, one that is playing out in the overwhelmingly male Republican-led Senate during a midterm election that has energized Democratic women. Ms. Fordâs attorney, Debra Katz, told CNN on Monday that Ms. Ford was willing to testify before Congress, if asked. One Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Jeff Flake of Arizona, told Politico that he was ânot comfortable voting yesâ on the nomination until he learned more about Ms. Fordâs account. A single Republican objection on the committee, which has 11 Republicans and 10 Democrats, could force a delay. Another Republican on the panel, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, said on Twitter that âif Ms. Ford wishes to provide information to the committee, I would gladly listen to what she has to say and compare that against all other information we have received about Judge Kavanaugh.â But he said he hoped to keep the process on schedule. Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, made a similar statement to Politico. Ms. Fordâs account comes as Democrats are already raising questions about Judge Kavanaughâs truthfulness during his confirmation hearings this month. They have accused him of dissembling on a range of issues from his time in the George W. Bush White House, including a breach of secret Democratic files on judicial nominations and discussions about detainee policy and torture. The new revelation prompted a hurried effort by Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the Judiciary Committee chairman, to set up conference calls to allow Democratic and Republican aides to interview both Judge Kavanaugh and Ms. Ford before Thursdayâs scheduled committee vote. A spokesman, Garrett Ventry, said it was routine to hold such calls âwhen updates are made to nomineesâ background files.â Senate Republican leaders in the hours after The Postâs article was published indicated that they intended to move forward with voting on him. Republicans planned to argue that unless corroborating information came to light, they had no way of verifying her story and saw no reason to delay the vote, according to a person involved in the discussions. The decision about any delay in the vote could rest on the opinions of two Republican women: Senators Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Susan Collins of Maine. Both are publicly undecided about Judge Kavanaugh. Ms. Collins said in an interview on Sunday night that she considered the allegations serious and that Ms. Ford needed to be personally interviewed to get a fuller account. But Ms. Collins, who could conceivably decide the outcome in the narrowly divided Senate, said Democrats had done a disservice to both Ms. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh with their handling of the accusations. âWhat is puzzling to me is the Democrats, by not bringing this out earlier, after having had this information for more than six weeks, have managed to cast a cloud of doubt on both the professor and the judge,â she said. âIf they believed Professor Ford, why didnât they surface this information earlier so that he could be questioned about it? And if they didnât believe her and chose to withhold the information, why did they decide at the 11th hour to release it? It is really not fair to either of them the way it is was handled.â The White House, which has taken great pains to portray Judge Kavanaugh as a champion of women, sought to bolster him by pointing to statements by women who have known him and testified to his character. Those included a letter from 65 women who said that they knew him in high school and that he had âalways treated women with decency and respect.â Advisers to Mr. Trump were trying to avoid publicly assailing the accuser while hoping that the lack of contemporaneous corroboration for Ms. Fordâs account would mean that Senate Republicans could move ahead without addressing it in detail. More delicately, advisers were privately urging Mr. Trump, who has been accused of sexual harassment by more than a dozen women, not to speak out about the allegations against Judge Kavanaugh on Twitter for fear that he would only inflame the situation. Still, some of the presidentâs allies on the right excoriated Ms. Ford â a registered Democrat â as a partisan. But Democrats and their liberal allies rallied around her, praising her courage and deeming her allegations credible. Senator Dianne Feinstein, the top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, called the accusations âextremely seriousâ and said they âbear heavily on Judge Kavanaughâs character.â She urged critics of his accuser to stop âthe attacks and stop shaming her.â Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, went one step further, invoking Anita Hill, who came forward during Justice Clarence Thomasâs 1991 confirmation hearings to accuse him of sexual harassment. âI was motivated to run for the Senate after watching the truly awful way Anita Hill was treated by an all-male Judiciary Committee interrogating her about the sexual harassment she endured at the hands of now-Justice Clarence Thomas,â Ms. Murray said in a statement, adding that the hearings must be delayed. There is an important difference between the two cases, however: Ms. Hill detailed harassment that took place in the workplace, when she and Justice Thomas were adults. The Postâs article included an interview with Ms. Fordâs husband and her lawyer, Ms. Katz, and described a therapistâs notes from 2012 in which Ms. Ford told of the attack. At Ms. Katzâs urging, Ms. Ford also underwent a polygraph examination in early August; the retired F.B.I. agent who conducted the examination, Jerry Hanafin, said in an interview on Sunday that the results showed âno deception indicatedâ â in effect, âshe was being truthful.â Her account has also been detailed in a confidential letter that Ms. Feinstein has shared with the F.B.I. She disclosed its existence on Thursday, although she had been in possession of it since late July. Most lawmakers have yet to read the letter Ms. Feinstein sent to the F.B.I., and Senate aides and lawmakers were privately weighing the implications of Ms. Fordâs interview on Sunday. Republicans on the Judiciary Committee said that if Ms. Feinstein had taken the allegations seriously, she should have brought them up earlier. âIt raises a lot of questions about Democratsâ tactics and motives to bring this to the rest of the committeeâs attention only now,â the statement said. But Ms. Katz said that throughout August, Ms. Feinsteinâs aides had checked back with Ms. Katz from time to time to see if Ms. Ford would go public. But Ms. Ford, fearing she would be attacked, wanted to remain private, and the senator respected her wishes, Ms. Katz said. She said Ms. Ford decided to reveal herself only because journalists began contacting her, and inaccurate stories about her began circulating. âWe do think that Feinstein did well by her, and we do think that people took this decision away from her, and thatâs wrong,â Ms. Katz said. âIf the #MeToo era teaches us anything, itâs that a person gets to choose when, where and how, and now this person is going to be injected into a life-altering blood bath.â The New York Times published an account of the letter on Friday. In her interview with The Post, Ms. Ford offered further detail, saying that one summer in the early 1980s, Mr. Kavanaugh and a friend, both âstumbling drunk,â led her into a bedroom at a home in Montgomery County, Md., in suburban Washington, where teenagers had gathered. The woman was wearing a bathing suit under her clothes. While his friend watched, the woman said, Mr. Kavanaugh pinned her down, grinding his body against hers and trying to pull off her one-piece bathing suit and the clothing she wore over it. She said she was able to escape when Mr. Kavanaughâs friend, Mark Judge, jumped on top of them, sending all three tumbling. She told The Post that she ran from the room, briefly locked herself in a bathroom and then fled the house. In the interview, Ms. Ford said the lasting trauma from the attack had âderailed me substantially for four or five years,â and had caused anxiety for years after that. Judge Kavanaugh, in a statement released last week, said: âI categorically and unequivocally deny this allegation. I did not do this back in high school or at any time.â In an interview with The Times on Friday, Mr. Judge, who had learned from reporters that he was the other student named in the letter, denied that any such episode had taken place. âIt never happened,â he said. âI never saw anything like what was described.â Further, he said it did not match Mr. Kavanaughâs character: âIt is not who he is.â Ms. Fordâs account opens a window into the exclusive prep school culture in which Mr. Kavanaugh grew up. The alleged assault occurred while he was a student at Georgetown Preparatory School, and Ms. Ford was a student at another private school, Holton-Arms, where she was a cheerleader in her senior year. She graduated in 1984. Reporting was contributed by Carl Hulse, Peter Baker, Nicholas Fandos, Maggie Haberman, Michael S. Schmidt, Steve Eder, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Grace Ashford.     Advertisement

description: Tuesday: “Game of Thrones” and “Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” win top awards, Brett Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford will testify, and tech C.E.O.s show off their musical skills.
title: California Today: California Today: Emmys Reflect Industry Tensions in 2018
text: Advertisement Supported by California Today By Jose A. Del Real and Inyoung Kang Good morning. (Want to get California Today by email? Hereâs the sign-up.) The 70th Primetime Emmys last night in Los Angeles had all the familiar trappings of Hollywood award shows: red carpet photo shoots, dramatic envelope rites, stiff banter and celebrity close-ups. In many ways, though, the show reflected the tensions and changes animating the television industry in 2018. Two running themes throughout the ceremony â prompting speculation long before the night kicked off â were the growing role streaming services have played in recent years and the intensifying push for diversity in casting and directing. This year, Netflix led the pack with 112 nominations and ended HBOâs 17-year streak as the most nominated platform. In the end, Netflix and HBO called it a tie; both came away with 23 Emmys each. HBO claimed the top prize when âGame of Thronesâ won for best drama. But it was Amazon that won for best comedy series for âThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,â one of five awards the show received at the ceremony. Notably, this year the Emmys boasted the most diverse group of nominees in its history â as those who watched the program were reminded a number of times. âYes indeedy, one step closer to a black Sheldon,â joked Kenan Thompson of âSaturday Night Live,â referring to the lead character in âThe Big Bang Theory.â Comedians and presenters throughout the evening were quick to mock premature back-patting on inclusion and sexual harassment. A whimsical but pointed musical segment opened the show: âWe solved it!â Kate McKinnon and Mr. Thompson sang. Throughout the number they were joined by Sterling K. Brown, Tituss Burgess, Kristen Bell, Ricky Martin and John Legend. (The actual point was: They have not solved it.) Amid the ceremonies, one unscripted moment nearly stole the whole show: The director Glenn Weiss â who won in the variety special category for directing last yearâs Oscars â drew stunned cheers and an outpouring on social media when he proposed to his girlfriend live on stage. She said yes. The winners in top categories: Best drama: âGame of Thronesâ (HBO) Best comedy: âThe Marvelous Mrs. Maiselâ (Amazon) Best limited series: âThe Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Storyâ (FX) Best actress, comedy: Rachel Brosnahan, âThe Marvelous Mrs. Maiselâ Best actor, comedy: Bill Hader, âBarryâ Best actress, drama: Claire Foy, âThe Crownâ Best actor, drama: Matthew Rhys, âThe Americansâ The full list of winners is here. And for an overview of the awards, click here. (Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.) â¢ The Supreme Court nominee Brett M. Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford, the Palo Alto research psychologist who accused him of sexual assault, will both testify in a Senate hearing on Monday. [The New York Times] â¢ Dr. Blasey feared an avalanche of attacks if she came forward, two of her close friends said. [The Mercury News] â¢ The case echoes Anita F. Hillâs in 1991, but this time the battle takes place in the #MeToo era. âI am stunned that this is happening again,â said Barbara Boxer, who was part of a group of female representatives who demanded a fair hearing for Ms. Hill. [The New York Times] â¢ The Trump administration announced a new cap of 30,000 for resettling refugees, a record low since the program began in 1980. [The New York Times] â¢ Gavin Newsom, the Democratic candidate for governor, and John Cox, his Republican challenger, have agreed to a live radio debate on Oct. 8. [KQED] â¢ When a San Francisco tech mogul buys a fabled slice of New York media: Marc Benioffâs purchase of Time magazine would have been unthinkable to generations of editors, our reporters write. [The New York Times] â¢ Mr. Benioff answered several questions about the deal by text message â while getting a massage. [The New York Times] â¢ Meet the Japanese billionaire who is SpaceXâs first customer for a voyage around the moon. [The New York Times] â¢ Elon Musk was sued by Vernon Unsworth, the British cave explorer he had accused of being a pedophile after the two butted heads over the rescue in Thailand over the summer. [The New York Times] â¢ The Justice Department will oppose colleges and universities that stifle free speech on campus, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said. He added that the Justice Department has statements of interest in four lawsuits, including in cases at U.C. Berkeley and Pierce College in Los Angeles. [The New York Times] â¢ A prominent architecture professor who was suspended from Berkeley for sexually harassing a student and abusing his power has resigned from the university. [The San Francisco Chronicle] â¢ Three homeless men are in critical condition after they were beaten with a baseball bat while they slept in downtown Los Angeles. [The Los Angeles Times] â¢ More than 200,000 drivers could lose the clean-air decals that allow them access to the car pool lane. [The Los Angeles Times] â¢ In memoriam: Big Jay McNeely, the Angeleno who was hailed as King of the Honkers for his wailing tenor saxophone, which helped establish the instrument at the dawn of rock ânâ roll. [The New York Times] â¢ Whatâs it like going to Burning Man for the first time? [Business Insider] Now trending in the Bay Area: the shofar, an ancient Jewish horn. So far the two most prominent figures showing off their musical skills are tech billionaires â Mark Zuckerberg and Marc Benioff, to be exact. Mr. Benioff played the shofar for the Jewish new year at a synagogue in San Francisco, where he was backed by a guitarist, the holy ark and a toddler wielding a purple plastic horn. Mr. Zuckerberg posted a video of himself playing the instrument in his Palo Alto home, where he was accompanied by the offscreen wailing of his 1-year-old daughter, August. âDear Mark,â one person commented on the Facebook clip, âI wish you new algorithms.â Read the full story here. California Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Tell us what you want to see: CAtoday@nytimes.com. California Today is edited by Julie Bloom, who grew up in Los Angeles and graduated from U.C. Berkeley. Advertisement
